column2: '11Oct'
column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person

column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America

I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind

column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column9: for example

column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary

column18: I think

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history

column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. column2: '11Oct'
column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 1)	" I have
column4: I have. First question is what's in the best interests of the United States? What's in the best interests of our people? When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question. Is it in our nation's interests? Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests. Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests. Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest. I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president. I also understand that an administration is not one person
column5: but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country
column6: to serve a cause greater than self
column7: and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America
column8: but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy. I haven't started naming names except for one person
column9: and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night. He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him. He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side. One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people. I've been able to set clear goals. The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column10: Medicare for our seniors
column11: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column12: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column13: and a strong military
column14: and then bring people together to achieve those goals. That's what a Chief Executive Officer does. So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.

column2: Jim. I've thought a lot about that particular question
column3: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world. I see it as a question of values. It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be. And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans. It's really true
column4: even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us. As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely
column5: they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more
column6: freedom
column7: free markets
column8: political freedom. So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union. The power of example is America's greatest power in the world. And that means
column9: for example
column10: standing up for human rights. It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity
column11: along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home
column12: because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems
column13: when they feel hope
column14: it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential. So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws. We've got to deal with things like racial profiling. And we have to keep our military strong. We have the strongest military
column15: and I'll do whatever is necessary
column16: if I'm president
column17: to make sure that it stays that way. But our real power comes
column18: I think
column19: from our values.

column2: I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from
column3: that you can succeed. I don't think they'll look at us with envy. It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy. If we're an arrogant nation
column4: they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation
column5: but strong
column6: they'll welcome us. And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power
column7: and that's why we have to be humble. And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom. So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are. We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way
column8: but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.

column1: I agree with that. I agree with that. I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history
column2: that I know about
column3: anyway. That there is some resentment of U.S. power. So I think that the idea of humility is an important one. But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world. We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about. That means not only military strength and our values
column4: it also means keeping our economy strong. You know
column5: in the last
column6: or two decades ago
column7: it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world
column8: and we were lectured to all the time. The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough. We need to do more. But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.

column2: it does. Take
column3: for example
column4: Third World debt. I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions. I think
column5: for example
column6: if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself
column7: that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people
column8: I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way
column9: or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands
column10: makes that much sense
column11: yes. We do have an obligation
column12: but we can't be all things to all people. We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world. We can lend money but we have to do it wisely. We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials. So we got to be guarded in our generosity.

column20: ""One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people.""
column21: ""I've been able to set clear goals.""
column22: ""The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind
column23: Medicare for our seniors
column24: a Social Security system that's safe and secure
column25: foreign policy that's in our nation's interest
column26: and a strong military
column27: and then bring people together to achieve those goals.""
column28: ""That's what a Chief Executive Officer does.""
column29: ""So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.""

column32: ""I've thought a lot about that particular question
column33: and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world.""
column34: 'I see it as a question of values.'
column35: 'It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be.'
column36: ""And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans.""

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 2)	" The first priority has to be on ending the violence
column4: dampening down the tensions that have arisen there. We need to call upon Syria to release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured. We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on. I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats
column5: and he needs to understand that he's not only dealing with Israel
column6: he is dealing -- he's dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that he's talking about there. The use of diplomacy in this situation has already
column7: well
column8: it goes hour-by-hour and day-by-day now. It's a very tense situation there. But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there. It's too much to hope that this is going to continue
column9: but I do hope that it will continue. Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there. And we just have to take it day-to-day right now. But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned
column10: Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing. Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives. They are historic
column11: they are strong
column12: and they are enduring. And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd.

column2: I think during the campaign
column3: particularly now during this difficult period
column4: we ought to be speaking with one voice
column5: and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions. Like the vice president
column6: I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace. I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East. I want everybody to know should I be the president Israel's going to be our friend. I'm going to stand by Israel. Secondly
column7: that I think it's important to reach out to moderate Arab nations
column8: like Jordan and Egypt
column9: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. It's important to be friends with people when you don't need each other so that when you do there's a strong bond of friendship. And that's going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel
column10: but with Saddam Hussein. The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or it's unraveling
column11: let's put it that way. The sanctions are being violated. We don't know whether he's developing weapons of mass destruction. He better not be or there's going to be a consequence should I be the president. But it's important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination. One of the reasons why I think it's important for this nation to develop an anti-ballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam Husseinâ€™s of the world or the Iranians
column12: don't dare threaten our friends. It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East
column13: credible ties
column14: because of the energy crisis we're now in. After all
column15: a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East
column16: and so I appreciate what the administration is doing. I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.

column2: we stand with Israel
column3: but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker. And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts
column4: especially during times of tension
column5: unless that dialogue comes through us. And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker
column6: then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.

column1: I do. I do think this
column2: though. When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place. It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to
column3: like the Palestinians and Israelis. Secondly
column4: any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides. And therefore
column5: the term honest broker makes sense. This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table. I will try to do the same thing. But it won't be on my timetable
column6: it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.

column1: I haven't heard a big difference in the last few exchanges.
That's hard to tell. I think that
column2: you know
column3: I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better.

column2: of course
column3: and I presume this administration would as well. We don't know -- there are no inspectors now in Iraq
column4: the coalition that was in place isn't as strong as it used to be. He is a danger. We don't want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East. And it's going to be hard
column5: it's going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him.

column2: when I got to be a part of the current administration
column3: it was right after -- I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution
column4: and at the end of that war
column5: for whatever reason
column6: it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power. I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations. But the fact is that that's the situation that was left when I got there. And we have maintained the sanctions. Now I want to go further. I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein
column7: and I know there are allegations that they're too weak to do it
column8: but that's what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia
column9: and you know
column10: the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week
column11: and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there
column12: building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block
column13: seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions. I know the governor's not necessarily saying that but
column14: you know
column15: all of these flights that have come in
column16: all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime
column17: I'm told
column18: except for three where they notified
column19: and they're trying to break out of the box
column20: there's no question about it. I don't think they should be allowed to.

column2: of course not
column3: absolutely not
column4: I want them to be tougher.

column12: don't dare threaten our friends. It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East
column13: credible ties
column14: because of the energy crisis we're now in. After all
column15: a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East
column16: and so I appreciate what the administration is doing. I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.

column2: we stand with Israel
column3: but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker. And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts
column4: especially during times of tension
column5: unless that dialogue comes through us. And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker
column6: then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.

column1: I do. I do think this
column2: though. When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place. It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to
column3: like the Palestinians and Israelis. Secondly
column4: any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides. And therefore
column5: the term honest broker makes sense. This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table. I will try to do the same thing. But it won't be on my timetable
column6: it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.

column1: I haven't heard a big difference in the last few exchanges.
That's hard to tell. I think that
column2: you know
column3: I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better.

column2: of course
column3: and I presume this administration would as well. We don't know -- there are no inspectors now in Iraq
column4: the coalition that was in place isn't as strong as it used to be. He is a danger. We don't want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East. And it's going to be hard
column5: it's going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him.

column2: when I got to be a part of the current administration
column3: it was right after -- I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution
column4: and at the end of that war
column5: for whatever reason
column6: it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power. I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations. But the fact is that that's the situation that was left when I got there. And we have maintained the sanctions. Now I want to go further. I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein
column7: and I know there are allegations that they're too weak to do it
column8: but that's what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia
column9: and you know
column10: the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week
column11: and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there
column12: building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block
column13: seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions. I know the governor's not necessarily saying that but
column14: you know
column15: all of these flights that have come in
column16: all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime
column17: I'm told
column18: except for three where they notified
column19: and they're trying to break out of the box
column20: there's no question about it. I don't think they should be allowed to.

column2: of course not
column3: absolutely not
column4: I want them to be tougher.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 2)	" The first priority has to be on ending the violence
column4: dampening down the tensions that have arisen there. We need to call upon Syria to release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured. We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on. I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats
column5: and he needs to understand that he's not only dealing with Israel
column6: he is dealing -- he's dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that he's talking about there. The use of diplomacy in this situation has already
column7: well
column8: it goes hour-by-hour and day-by-day now. It's a very tense situation there. But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there. It's too much to hope that this is going to continue
column9: but I do hope that it will continue. Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there. And we just have to take it day-to-day right now. But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned
column10: Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing. Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives. They are historic
column11: they are strong
column12: and they are enduring. And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd.

column2: I think during the campaign
column3: particularly now during this difficult period
column4: we ought to be speaking with one voice
column5: and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions. Like the vice president
column6: I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace. I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East. I want everybody to know should I be the president Israel's going to be our friend. I'm going to stand by Israel. Secondly
column7: that I think it's important to reach out to moderate Arab nations
column8: like Jordan and Egypt
column9: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. It's important to be friends with people when you don't need each other so that when you do there's a strong bond of friendship. And that's going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel
column10: but with Saddam Hussein. The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or it's unraveling
column11: let's put it that way. The sanctions are being violated. We don't know whether he's developing weapons of mass destruction. He better not be or there's going to be a consequence should I be the president. But it's important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination. One of the reasons why I think it's important for this nation to develop an anti-ballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam Husseinâ€™s of the world or the Iranians
column12: don't dare threaten our friends. It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East
column13: credible ties
column14: because of the energy crisis we're now in. After all
column15: a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East
column16: and so I appreciate what the administration is doing. I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.

column2: we stand with Israel
column3: but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker. And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts
column4: especially during times of tension
column5: unless that dialogue comes through us. And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker
column6: then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.

column1: I do. I do think this
column2: though. When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place. It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to
column3: like the Palestinians and Israelis. Secondly
column4: any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides. And therefore
column5: the term honest broker makes sense. This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table. I will try to do the same thing. But it won't be on my timetable
column6: it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 2)	" The first priority has to be on ending the violence
column4: dampening down the tensions that have arisen there. We need to call upon Syria to release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured. We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on. I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats
column5: and he needs to understand that he's not only dealing with Israel
column6: he is dealing -- he's dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that he's talking about there. The use of diplomacy in this situation has already
column7: well
column8: it goes hour-by-hour and day-by-day now. It's a very tense situation there. But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there. It's too much to hope that this is going to continue
column9: but I do hope that it will continue. Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there. And we just have to take it day-to-day right now. But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned
column10: Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing. Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives. They are historic
column11: they are strong
column12: and they are enduring. And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd.

column2: I think during the campaign
column3: particularly now during this difficult period
column4: we ought to be speaking with one voice
column5: and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions. Like the vice president
column6: I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace. I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East. I want everybody to know should I be the president Israel's going to be our friend. I'm going to stand by Israel. Secondly
column7: that I think it's important to reach out to moderate Arab nations
column8: like Jordan and Egypt
column9: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. It's important to be friends with people when you don't need each other so that when you do there's a strong bond of friendship. And that's going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel
column10: but with Saddam Hussein. The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or it's unraveling
column11: let's put it that way. The sanctions are being violated. We don't know whether he's developing weapons of mass destruction. He better not be or there's going to be a consequence should I be the president. But it's important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination. One of the reasons why I think it's important for this nation to develop an anti-ballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam Husseinâ€™s of the world or the Iranians
column12: don't dare threaten our friends. It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East
column13: credible ties
column14: because of the energy crisis we're now in. After all
column15: a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East
column16: and so I appreciate what the administration is doing. I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.

column2: we stand with Israel
column3: but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker. And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts
column4: especially during times of tension
column5: unless that dialogue comes through us. And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker
column6: then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.

column1: I do. I do think this
column2: though. When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place. It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to
column3: like the Palestinians and Israelis. Secondly
column4: any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides. And therefore
column5: the term honest broker makes sense. This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table. I will try to do the same thing. But it won't be on my timetable
column6: it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.

column1: I haven't heard a big difference in the last few exchanges.
That's hard to tell. I think that
column2: you know
column3: I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better.

column2: of course
column3: and I presume this administration would as well. We don't know -- there are no inspectors now in Iraq
column4: the coalition that was in place isn't as strong as it used to be. He is a danger. We don't want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East. And it's going to be hard
column5: it's going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him.

column2: when I got to be a part of the current administration
column3: it was right after -- I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution
column4: and at the end of that war
column5: for whatever reason
column6: it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power. I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations. But the fact is that that's the situation that was left when I got there. And we have maintained the sanctions. Now I want to go further. I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein
column7: and I know there are allegations that they're too weak to do it
column8: but that's what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia
column9: and you know
column10: the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week
column11: and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there
column12: building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block
column13: seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions. I know the governor's not necessarily saying that but
column14: you know
column15: all of these flights that have come in
column16: all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime
column17: I'm told
column18: except for three where they notified
column19: and they're trying to break out of the box
column20: there's no question about it. I don't think they should be allowed to.

column2: of course not
column3: absolutely not
column4: I want them to be tougher.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 2)	" The first priority has to be on ending the violence
column4: dampening down the tensions that have arisen there. We need to call upon Syria to release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured. We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on. I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats
column5: and he needs to understand that he's not only dealing with Israel
column6: he is dealing -- he's dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that he's talking about there. The use of diplomacy in this situation has already
column7: well
column8: it goes hour-by-hour and day-by-day now. It's a very tense situation there. But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there. It's too much to hope that this is going to continue
column9: but I do hope that it will continue. Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there. And we just have to take it day-to-day right now. But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned
column10: Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing. Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives. They are historic
column11: they are strong
column12: and they are enduring. And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd.

column2: I think during the campaign
column3: particularly now during this difficult period
column4: we ought to be speaking with one voice
column5: and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions. Like the vice president
column6: I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace. I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East. I want everybody to know should I be the president Israel's going to be our friend. I'm going to stand by Israel. Secondly
column7: that I think it's important to reach out to moderate Arab nations
column8: like Jordan and Egypt
column9: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. It's important to be friends with people when you don't need each other so that when you do there's a strong bond of friendship. And that's going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel
column10: but with Saddam Hussein. The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or it's unraveling
column11: let's put it that way. The sanctions are being violated. We don't know whether he's developing weapons of mass destruction. He better not be or there's going to be a consequence should I be the president. But it's important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination. One of the reasons why I think it's important for this nation to develop an anti-ballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam Husseinâ€™s of the world or the Iranians
column12: don't dare threaten our friends. It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East
column13: credible ties
column14: because of the energy crisis we're now in. After all
column15: a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East
column16: and so I appreciate what the administration is doing. I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.

column2: we stand with Israel
column3: but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker. And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts
column4: especially during times of tension
column5: unless that dialogue comes through us. And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker
column6: then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.

column1: I do. I do think this
column2: though. When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place. It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to
column3: like the Palestinians and Israelis. Secondly
column4: any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides. And therefore
column5: the term honest broker makes sense. This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table. I will try to do the same thing. But it won't be on my timetable
column6: it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.

column1: I haven't heard a big difference in the last few exchanges.
That's hard to tell. I think that
column2: you know
column3: I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better.

column2: of course
column3: and I presume this administration would as well. We don't know -- there are no inspectors now in Iraq
column4: the coalition that was in place isn't as strong as it used to be. He is a danger. We don't want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East. And it's going to be hard
column5: it's going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him.

column2: when I got to be a part of the current administration
column3: it was right after -- I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution
column4: and at the end of that war
column5: for whatever reason
column6: it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power. I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations. But the fact is that that's the situation that was left when I got there. And we have maintained the sanctions. Now I want to go further. I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein
column7: and I know there are allegations that they're too weak to do it
column8: but that's what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia
column9: and you know
column10: the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week
column11: and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there
column12: building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block
column13: seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions. I know the governor's not necessarily saying that but
column14: you know
column15: all of these flights that have come in
column16: all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime
column17: I'm told
column18: except for three where they notified
column19: and they're trying to break out of the box
column20: there's no question about it. I don't think they should be allowed to.

column2: of course not
column3: absolutely not
column4: I want them to be tougher.

release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured', 'We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on', 'I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats, and he needs to understand that hes not only dealing with Israel, he is dealing  hes dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that hes talking about there', 'The use of diplomacy in this situation has already, well, it goes hourbyhour and daybyday now', 'Its a very tense situation there', 'But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there', 'Its too much to hope that this is going to continue, but I do hope that it will continue', 'Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there', 'And we just have to take it daytoday right now', 'But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned, Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing', 'Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives', 'They are historic, they are strong, and they are enduring', 'And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd', 'Well, I think during the campaign, particularly now during this difficult period, we ought to be speaking with one voice, and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions', 'Like the vice president, I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace', 'I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East', 'I want everybody to know should I be the president Israels going to be our friend', 'Im going to stand by Israel', 'Secondly, that I think its important to reach out to moderate Arab nations, like Jordan and Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait', 'Its important to be friends with people when you dont need each other so that when you do theres a strong bond of friendship', 'And thats going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel, but with Saddam Hussein', 'The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or its unraveling, lets put it that way', 'The sanctions are being violated', 'We dont know whether hes developing weapons of mass destruction', 'He better not be or theres going to be a consequence should I be the president', 'But its important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination', 'One of the reasons why I think its important for this nation to develop an antiballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam Husseinâ€™s of the world or the Iranians, dont dare threaten our friends', 'Its also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East, credible ties, because of the energy crisis were now in', 'After all, a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East, and so I appreciate what the administration is doing', 'I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East', 'Well, we stand with Israel, but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker', 'And one of the reasons thats important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts, especially during times of tension, unless that dialogue comes through us', 'And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker, then we have thrown  we will have thrown away a strategic asset thats important not only to us but also to Israel', 'I do', 'I do think this, though', 'When it comes to timetables it cant be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place', 'Its got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to, like the Palestinians and Israelis', 'Secondly, any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace thats good for both sides', 'And therefore, the term honest broker makes sense', 'This current administrations worked hard to keep the parties at the table', 'I will try to do the same thing', 'But it wont be on my timetable, it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East', 'I havent heard a big difference in the last few exchanges', 'Thats hard to tell', 'I think that, you know, I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better', 'I would like to, of course, and I presume this administration would as well', 'We dont know  there are no inspectors now in Iraq, the coalition that was in place isnt as strong as it used to be', 'He is a danger', 'We dont want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East', 'And its going to be hard, its going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him', 'I do', 'Well, when I got to be a part of the current administration, it was right after  I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution, and at the end of that war, for whatever reason, it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power', 'I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations', 'But the fact is that thats the situation that was left when I got there', 'And we have maintained the sanctions', 'Now I want to go further', 'I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein, and I know there are allegations that theyre too weak to do it, but thats what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia, and you know, the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week, and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there, building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block, seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions', 'I know the governors not necessarily saying that but, you know, all of these flights that have come in, all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime, Im told, except for three where they notified, and theyre trying to break out of the box, theres no question about it', 'I dont think they should be allowed to', 'No, of course not, absolutely not, I want them to be tougher']	['The first priority has to be on ending the violence
