column2: '11Oct'
column3: 3)	" I think it's a triumph. I thought the president made the right decision in joining NATO and bombing Serbia. I supported them when they did so. I called upon the Congress not to hamstring the administration
column4: and in terms of forcing troop withdrawals on a timetable that wasn't necessarily in our best interest or fit our nation's strategy
column5: and so I think it's good public policy
column6: I think it worked
column7: and I'm pleased I took -- made the decision I made. I'm pleased the president made the decision he made. Because freedom took hold in that part of the world
column8: but there's a lot of work left to be done
column9: however.

column2: I think it is. Absolutely. I don't think he would have fallen had we not used the force. And I know there are some in our party that disagree with that sentiment. I supported the president. I thought he made the right decision to do so. I didn't think he necessarily made the right decision to take land troops off the table right before we committed ourselves offensively
column3: but nevertheless
column4: it worked. The administration deserves credit for having made it work. It is important for NATO to have it work. It's important for NATO to be strong and confident and to help keep the peace in Europe. And one of the reasons I felt so strongly that the United States needed to participate was because of our relations with NATO
column5: and NATO is going to be an important part of keeping the peace in the future. Now
column6: there's more work to do. Remains to be seen
column7: however
column8: whether or not there's going to be a political settlement in Kosovo
column9: and I certainly hope there is one. Iâ€™m on record as saying at some point in time I hope our European friends become the peacekeepers in Bosnia and in the Balkans. I hope that they put the troops on the ground so that we can withdraw our troops and focus our military on fighting and winning war.

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy
column4: and he's still going to try to be actively involved. He is an indicted war criminal. He should be held accountable. Now
column5: I did want to pick up on one of the statements earlier
column6: and maybe I have heard
column7: maybe I have heard the previous statements wrong
column8: Governor. In some of the discussions we've had about when it's appropriate for the U.S. to use force around the world
column9: at times the standards that you've laid down have given me the impression that if it's something like a genocide taking place or what they called ethnic cleansing in Bosnia
column10: that that alone would not be
column11: that that wouldn't be the kind of situation that would cause you to think that the U.S. ought to get involved with troops. Now
column12: have to be other factors involved for me to want to be involved. But by itself
column13: that to me can bring into play a fundamental American strategic interest because I think it's based on our values. Now
column14: have I got that wrong?

column1: Trying to figure out who the questioner was. If I think it's in our nation's strategic interest I'll commit troops. I thought it was in our strategic interests to keep Milosevic in check because of our relations in NATO
column2: and that's why I took the position I took. I think it's important for NATO to be strong and confident. I felt like unchecked Milosevic would harm NATO
column3: and so it depends on the situation
column4: Mr. Vice President.

column1: Can you run through the list again?
I thought that was a mistake.

column2: I voted for it
column3: supported it.

column2: and that again -- no
column3: I think that that was ill-considered. I did support it at the time. It was in the previous administration
column4: in the Bush-Quayle administration
column5: and I think in retrospect the lessons there are ones that we should take very
column6: very seriously.

column2: yes.

column1: Started off as a humanitarian mission and it changed into a nation-building mission
column2: and that's where the mission went wrong. The mission was changed. And as a result
column3: our nation paid a price. And so I don't think our troops ought to be used for what's called nation-building. I think our troops ought to be used to fight and win war. I think our troops ought to be used to help overthrow the dictator when it's in our best interests. But in this case it was a nation-building exercise
column4: and same with Haiti. I wouldn't have supported either.

column1: Yes. Some of them I've got a conflict of interest on
column2: if you know what I mean.

column1: I think the administration did the right thing in that case. I do. It was a horrible situation
column2: no one liked to see it on our TV screens
column3: but it's a case where we need to make sure we have an early warning system in place in places where there could be ethnic cleansing and genocide the way we saw it there in Rwanda. And that's a case where we need to use our influence to have countries in Africa come together and help deal with the situation. The administration
column4: seems like we're having a great love fest tonight
column5: but the administration made the right decision on training Nigerian troops for situations just such as this in Rwanda
column6: and so I thought they made the right decision not to send U.S. troops into Rwanda.

column1: I'd like to come back to the question of nation building
column2: but let me address the question directly
column3: first. Fine. We did
column4: actually
column5: send troops into Rwanda to help with the humanitarian relief measures. My wife Tipper
column6: who is here
column7: actually went on a military plane with General Sholicatchvieli on one of those flights. But I think in retrospect we were too late getting in there. We could have saved more lives if we had acted earlier. But I do not think that it was an example of a conflict where we should have put our troops in to try to separate the parties for this reason
column8: Jim. One of the criteria that I think is important in deciding when and if we should ever get involved around the world is whether or not our national security interest is involved
column9: if we can really make the difference with military forces. If we tried everything else
column10: if we have allies. In the Balkans we have allies
column11: NATO
column12: ready
column13: willing and able to go and carry a big part of the burden. In Africa we did not. Now
column14: we have tried -- our country has tried to create an Africa crisis response team there
column15: and we've met some resistance. We have had some luck with Nigeria
column16: but in Sierra Leon
column17: and now that Nigeria has become a democracy
column18: and we hope it stays that way
column19: then maybe we can build on that. But because we had no allies and because it was very unclear that we could actually accomplish what we would want to accomplish about putting military forces there
column20: I think it was the right thing not to jump in
column22: but I think we should have come in much quicker with the humanitarian mission.

column2: I understand
column3: and Africa is important. And we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade
column4: and there are some -- Vice President mentioned Nigeria is a fledgling democracy. We have to work with Nigeria. Itâ€™s an important continent. But there's got to be priorities
column5: and Middle East is a priority for a lot of reasons
column6: as is Europe and the Far East
column7: our own hemisphere. And those are my four top priorities should I be the president
column8: not to say we won't be engaged nor work hard to get other nations to come together to prevent atrocity. I thought the best example of a way to handle the situation was East Timor when we provided logistical support to the Australians
column9: support that only we can provide. I thought that was a good model. But we can't be all things to all people in the world
column10: Jim. And I think that's where maybe the vice president and I begin to have some differences. I'm worried about overcommitting our military around the world. I want to be judicious in its use. You mentioned Haiti. I wouldn't have sent troops to Haiti. I didn't think it was a mission worthwhile. It was a nation building mission
column11: and it was not very successful. It cost us billions
column12: a couple billions of dollars
column13: and I'm not so sure democracy is any better off in Haiti than it was before.

column1: I don't think we agree on that. I would certainly also be judicious in evaluating any potential use of American troops overseas. I think we have to be very reticent about that. But look
column2: Jim
column3: the world is changing so rapidly. The way I see it
column4: the world is getting much closer together. Like it or not
column5: we are now -- the United States is now the natural leader of the world. All these other countries are looking to us. Now
column6: just because we cannot be involved everywhere
column7: and shouldn't be
column8: doesn't mean that we should shy away from going in anywhere. Now
column9: both of us are kind of
column10: I guess
column11: stating the other's position in a maximalist extreme way
column12: but I think there is a difference here. This idea of nation building is kind of a pejorative phrase
column13: but think about the great conflict of the past century
column14: World War II. During the years between World War I and World War II
column15: a great lesson was learned by our military leaders and the people of the United States. The lesson was that in the aftermath of World War I
column16: we kind of turned our backs and left them to their own devices and they brewed up a lot of trouble that quickly became World War II. And acting upon that lesson in the aftermath of our great victory in World War II
column17: we laid down the Marshall Plan
column18: President Truman did. We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there. We still have lots of troops in Europe. And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's? We were nation building. And it was economic. But it was also military. And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there. We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.

column1: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said. I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy. And we can't do that. We've got to rebuild our military. But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world. And I mentioned one
column2: and that's the Balkans. I would very much like to get our troops out of there. I recognize we can't do it now
column3: nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground. And there is an example. Haiti is another example. Now there are some places where I think -- you know
column4: I've supported the administration in Columbia. I think it's important for us to be training Columbians in that part of the world. The hemisphere is in our interest to have a peaceful Columbia. But --

column1: I don't think so. I think what we need to do is convince people who live in the lands they live in to build the nations. Maybe I'm missing something here. I mean
column2: we're going to have kind of a nation building core from America? Absolutely not. Our military is meant to fight and win war. That's what it's meant to do. And when it gets overextended
column3: morale drops. I strongly believe we need to have a military presence in the Korean peninsula
column4: not only to keep the peace in the peninsula
column5: but to keep regional stability. And I strongly believe we need to keep a presence in NATO
column6: but I'm going to be judicious as to how to use the military. It needs to be in our vital interest
column7: the mission needs to be clear
column8: and the extra strategy obvious.

column1: I don't disagree with that. I certainly don't disagree that we ought to get our troops home from places like the Balkans as soon as we can
column2: as soon as the mission is complete. That's what we did in Haiti. There are no more than a handful of American military personnel in Haiti now. And Haitians have their problems
column3: but we gave them a chance to restore democracy. That's really about all we can do. But if you have a situation like that right in our backyard with chaos about to break out and flotillas forming to come across the water
column4: and all kinds of violence there
column5: right in one of our neighboring countries there
column6: then I think that we did the right thing there. And as for this idea of nation building
column7: the phrase sounds grandiose. And
column8: you know
column9: we can't be -- we can't allow ourselves to get overextended. I certainly agree with that. And that's why I've supported building up our capacity. I've devoted in the budget I've proposed
column10: as I said last week
column11: more than twice as much as the governor has proposed. I think that it's in better shape now than he generally does. We've had some disagreements about that. He said that two divisions would have to report not ready for duty
column12: and that's not what the joint chiefs say. But there's no doubt that we have to continue building up readiness and military strength. And we have to also be very cautious in the way we use our military.

column2: I mentioned Third World debt.

column1: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way
column2: influence nations. I believe we ought to have foreign aid
column3: but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid. I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform. I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way
column4: and there's some pretty egregious examples recently. One being Russia
column5: where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation. I think the IMF has got a role in the world
column6: but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers
column7: if you make a bad loan
column8: we'll bail you out. It needs to be available for emergency situations. I thought the President did the right thing with Mexico and was very strongly supportive of the administration in Mexico. But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves. So I'll look at every place where we're investing money. I just want to make sure the return is good.

column2: I would make some changes. I think there need to be reforms in the IMF. I've generally supported it
column3: but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable. And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF. The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job
column4: but I think one of the big issues here that doesn't get nearly enough attention is the issue of corruption. The governor mentioned it earlier. I've worked on this issue. It's an enormous problem and corruption in official agencies
column5: like militaries and police departments around the world
column6: customs officials
column7: that's one of the worst forms of it. And we have got to again lead by example and help these other countries that are trying to straighten out their situations find the tools in order to do it. I just think
column8: Jim
column9: that this is an absolutely unique period in world history. The worldâ€™s coming together
column10: as I said
column11: they're looking to us. And we have a fundamental choice to make. Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II
column12: the way that generation of heroes said okay
column13: the United States is going to be the leader. And the world benefitted tremendously from the courage that they showed in those post-war years. I think that in the aftermath of the Cold War
column14: it's time for us to do something very similar
column15: to step up to the plate
column16: to provide the leadership on the environment
column17: leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction. Again
column18: that means not running big deficits here and not squandering our surplus. It means having intelligent decisions that keep our prosperity going and shepherds that economic strength so that we can provide that leadership role.

column1: Let me comment on that. I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be. We can help. And maybe it's just our difference in government
column2: the way we view government. I want to empower the people. I want to help people help themselves
column3: not have government tell people what to do. I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country and say
column4: â€œwe do it this way
column5: so should you.â€ I think we can help. I know we've got to encourage democracy in the marketplaces. But take Russia
column6: for example. We went into Russia
column7: we said here is some IMF money
column8: and it ended up in Viktor Chemomyrdin's pocket
column9: and others
column10: and yet we played like there was reform. The only people that are going to reform Russia are Russia. They're going to have to make the decision themselves. Mr. Putin is going to have to make the decision as to whether or not he wants to adhere to rule of law and normal accounting practices so that if countries and/or entities invest capital
column11: there's a reasonable rate of return
column12: a way to get the money out of the economy. But Russia has to make the decision. We can work with them on security matters
column13: for example
column14: but it's their call to make. So I'm not exactly sure where the vice president is coming from
column15: but I think one way for us to end up being viewed as the ugly American is for us to go around the world saying
column16: â€œwe do it this way
column17: so should you.â€ Now
column18: we trust freedom. We know freedom is a powerful
column19: powerful
column20: powerful force
column21: much bigger than the United States of America
column22: as we saw recently in the Balkans. But maybe I misunderstand where you're coming from
column23: Mr. Vice President
column24: but I think the United States must be humble and must be proud and confident of our values
column25: but humble in how we treat nations that are figuring out how to chart their own course.

column1: Far be it from me to suggest otherwise. (LAUGHTER)

column3: 3)	" I think it's a triumph. I thought the president made the right decision in joining NATO and bombing Serbia. I supported them when they did so. I called upon the Congress not to hamstring the administration
column4: and in terms of forcing troop withdrawals on a timetable that wasn't necessarily in our best interest or fit our nation's strategy
column5: and so I think it's good public policy
column6: I think it worked
column7: and I'm pleased I took -- made the decision I made. I'm pleased the president made the decision he made. Because freedom took hold in that part of the world
column8: but there's a lot of work left to be done
column9: however.

column2: I think it is. Absolutely. I don't think he would have fallen had we not used the force. And I know there are some in our party that disagree with that sentiment. I supported the president. I thought he made the right decision to do so. I didn't think he necessarily made the right decision to take land troops off the table right before we committed ourselves offensively
column3: but nevertheless
column4: it worked. The administration deserves credit for having made it work. It is important for NATO to have it work. It's important for NATO to be strong and confident and to help keep the peace in Europe. And one of the reasons I felt so strongly that the United States needed to participate was because of our relations with NATO
column5: and NATO is going to be an important part of keeping the peace in the future. Now
column6: there's more work to do. Remains to be seen
column7: however
column8: whether or not there's going to be a political settlement in Kosovo
column9: and I certainly hope there is one. Iâ€™m on record as saying at some point in time I hope our European friends become the peacekeepers in Bosnia and in the Balkans. I hope that they put the troops on the ground so that we can withdraw our troops and focus our military on fighting and winning war.

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy
column4: and he's still going to try to be actively involved. He is an indicted war criminal. He should be held accountable. Now
column5: I did want to pick up on one of the statements earlier
column6: and maybe I have heard
column7: maybe I have heard the previous statements wrong
column8: Governor. In some of the discussions we've had about when it's appropriate for the U.S. to use force around the world
column9: at times the standards that you've laid down have given me the impression that if it's something like a genocide taking place or what they called ethnic cleansing in Bosnia
column10: that that alone would not be
column11: that that wouldn't be the kind of situation that would cause you to think that the U.S. ought to get involved with troops. Now
column12: have to be other factors involved for me to want to be involved. But by itself
column13: that to me can bring into play a fundamental American strategic interest because I think it's based on our values. Now
column14: have I got that wrong?

column1: Trying to figure out who the questioner was. If I think it's in our nation's strategic interest I'll commit troops. I thought it was in our strategic interests to keep Milosevic in check because of our relations in NATO
column2: and that's why I took the position I took. I think it's important for NATO to be strong and confident. I felt like unchecked Milosevic would harm NATO
column3: and so it depends on the situation
column4: Mr. Vice President.

column1: Can you run through the list again?
I thought that was a mistake.

column2: I voted for it
column3: supported it.

column2: and that again -- no
column3: I think that that was ill-considered. I did support it at the time. It was in the previous administration
column4: in the Bush-Quayle administration
column5: and I think in retrospect the lessons there are ones that we should take very
column6: very seriously.

column2: yes.

column1: Started off as a humanitarian mission and it changed into a nation-building mission
column2: and that's where the mission went wrong. The mission was changed. And as a result
column3: our nation paid a price. And so I don't think our troops ought to be used for what's called nation-building. I think our troops ought to be used to fight and win war. I think our troops ought to be used to help overthrow the dictator when it's in our best interests. But in this case it was a nation-building exercise
column4: and same with Haiti. I wouldn't have supported either.

column1: Yes. Some of them I've got a conflict of interest on
column2: if you know what I mean.

column1: I think the administration did the right thing in that case. I do. It was a horrible situation
column2: no one liked to see it on our TV screens
column3: but it's a case where we need to make sure we have an early warning system in place in places where there could be ethnic cleansing and genocide the way we saw it there in Rwanda. And that's a case where we need to use our influence to have countries in Africa come together and help deal with the situation. The administration
column4: seems like we're having a great love fest tonight
column5: but the administration made the right decision on training Nigerian troops for situations just such as this in Rwanda
column6: and so I thought they made the right decision not to send U.S. troops into Rwanda.

column1: I'd like to come back to the question of nation building
column2: but let me address the question directly
column3: first. Fine. We did
column4: actually
column5: send troops into Rwanda to help with the humanitarian relief measures. My wife Tipper
column6: who is here
column7: actually went on a military plane with General Sholicatchvieli on one of those flights. But I think in retrospect we were too late getting in there. We could have saved more lives if we had acted earlier. But I do not think that it was an example of a conflict where we should have put our troops in to try to separate the parties for this reason
column8: Jim. One of the criteria that I think is important in deciding when and if we should ever get involved around the world is whether or not our national security interest is involved
column9: if we can really make the difference with military forces. If we tried everything else
column10: if we have allies. In the Balkans we have allies
column11: NATO
column12: ready
column13: willing and able to go and carry a big part of the burden. In Africa we did not. Now
column14: we have tried -- our country has tried to create an Africa crisis response team there
column15: and we've met some resistance. We have had some luck with Nigeria
column16: but in Sierra Leon
column17: and now that Nigeria has become a democracy
column18: and we hope it stays that way
column19: then maybe we can build on that. But because we had no allies and because it was very unclear that we could actually accomplish what we would want to accomplish about putting military forces there
column20: I think it was the right thing not to jump in
column22: but I think we should have come in much quicker with the humanitarian mission.

column2: I understand
column3: and Africa is important. And we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade
column4: and there are some -- Vice President mentioned Nigeria is a fledgling democracy. We have to work with Nigeria. Itâ€™s an important continent. But there's got to be priorities
column5: and Middle East is a priority for a lot of reasons
column6: as is Europe and the Far East
column7: our own hemisphere. And those are my four top priorities should I be the president
column8: not to say we won't be engaged nor work hard to get other nations to come together to prevent atrocity. I thought the best example of a way to handle the situation was East Timor when we provided logistical support to the Australians
column9: support that only we can provide. I thought that was a good model. But we can't be all things to all people in the world
column10: Jim. And I think that's where maybe the vice president and I begin to have some differences. I'm worried about overcommitting our military around the world. I want to be judicious in its use. You mentioned Haiti. I wouldn't have sent troops to Haiti. I didn't think it was a mission worthwhile. It was a nation building mission
column11: and it was not very successful. It cost us billions
column12: a couple billions of dollars
column13: and I'm not so sure democracy is any better off in Haiti than it was before.

column1: I don't think we agree on that. I would certainly also be judicious in evaluating any potential use of American troops overseas. I think we have to be very reticent about that. But look
column2: Jim
column3: the world is changing so rapidly. The way I see it
column4: the world is getting much closer together. Like it or not
column5: we are now -- the United States is now the natural leader of the world. All these other countries are looking to us. Now
column6: just because we cannot be involved everywhere
column7: and shouldn't be
column8: doesn't mean that we should shy away from going in anywhere. Now
column9: both of us are kind of
column10: I guess
column11: stating the other's position in a maximalist extreme way
column12: but I think there is a difference here. This idea of nation building is kind of a pejorative phrase
column13: but think about the great conflict of the past century
column14: World War II. During the years between World War I and World War II
column15: a great lesson was learned by our military leaders and the people of the United States. The lesson was that in the aftermath of World War I
column16: we kind of turned our backs and left them to their own devices and they brewed up a lot of trouble that quickly became World War II. And acting upon that lesson in the aftermath of our great victory in World War II
column17: we laid down the Marshall Plan
column18: President Truman did. We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there. We still have lots of troops in Europe. And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's? We were nation building. And it was economic. But it was also military. And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there. We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.

column1: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said. I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy. And we can't do that. We've got to rebuild our military. But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world. And I mentioned one
column2: and that's the Balkans. I would very much like to get our troops out of there. I recognize we can't do it now
column3: nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground. And there is an example. Haiti is another example. Now there are some places where I think -- you know
column4: I've supported the administration in Columbia. I think it's important for us to be training Columbians in that part of the world. The hemisphere is in our interest to have a peaceful Columbia. But --

column1: I don't think so. I think what we need to do is convince people who live in the lands they live in to build the nations. Maybe I'm missing something here. I mean
column2: we're going to have kind of a nation building core from America? Absolutely not. Our military is meant to fight and win war. That's what it's meant to do. And when it gets overextended
column3: morale drops. I strongly believe we need to have a military presence in the Korean peninsula
column4: not only to keep the peace in the peninsula
column5: but to keep regional stability. And I strongly believe we need to keep a presence in NATO
column6: but I'm going to be judicious as to how to use the military. It needs to be in our vital interest
column7: the mission needs to be clear
column8: and the extra strategy obvious.

column1: I don't disagree with that. I certainly don't disagree that we ought to get our troops home from places like the Balkans as soon as we can
column2: as soon as the mission is complete. That's what we did in Haiti. There are no more than a handful of American military personnel in Haiti now. And Haitians have their problems
column3: but we gave them a chance to restore democracy. That's really about all we can do. But if you have a situation like that right in our backyard with chaos about to break out and flotillas forming to come across the water
column4: and all kinds of violence there
column5: right in one of our neighboring countries there
column6: then I think that we did the right thing there. And as for this idea of nation building
column7: the phrase sounds grandiose. And
column8: you know
column9: we can't be -- we can't allow ourselves to get overextended. I certainly agree with that. And that's why I've supported building up our capacity. I've devoted in the budget I've proposed
column10: as I said last week
column11: more than twice as much as the governor has proposed. I think that it's in better shape now than he generally does. We've had some disagreements about that. He said that two divisions would have to report not ready for duty
column12: and that's not what the joint chiefs say. But there's no doubt that we have to continue building up readiness and military strength. And we have to also be very cautious in the way we use our military.

column2: I mentioned Third World debt.

column1: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way
column2: influence nations. I believe we ought to have foreign aid
column3: but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid. I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform. I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way
column4: and there's some pretty egregious examples recently. One being Russia
column5: where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation. I think the IMF has got a role in the world
column6: but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers
column7: if you make a bad loan
column8: we'll bail you out. It needs to be available for emergency situations. I thought the President did the right thing with Mexico and was very strongly supportive of the administration in Mexico. But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves. So I'll look at every place where we're investing money. I just want to make sure the return is good.

column2: I would make some changes. I think there need to be reforms in the IMF. I've generally supported it
column3: but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable. And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF. The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job
column4: but I think one of the big issues here that doesn't get nearly enough attention is the issue of corruption. The governor mentioned it earlier. I've worked on this issue. It's an enormous problem and corruption in official agencies
column5: like militaries and police departments around the world
column6: customs officials
column7: that's one of the worst forms of it. And we have got to again lead by example and help these other countries that are trying to straighten out their situations find the tools in order to do it. I just think
column8: Jim
column9: that this is an absolutely unique period in world history. The worldâ€™s coming together
column10: as I said
column11: they're looking to us. And we have a fundamental choice to make. Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II
column12: the way that generation of heroes said okay
column13: the United States is going to be the leader. And the world benefitted tremendously from the courage that they showed in those post-war years. I think that in the aftermath of the Cold War
column14: it's time for us to do something very similar
column15: to step up to the plate
column16: to provide the leadership on the environment
column17: leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction. Again
column18: that means not running big deficits here and not squandering our surplus. It means having intelligent decisions that keep our prosperity going and shepherds that economic strength so that we can provide that leadership role.

column1: Let me comment on that. I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be. We can help. And maybe it's just our difference in government
column2: the way we view government. I want to empower the people. I want to help people help themselves
column3: not have government tell people what to do. I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country and say
column4: â€œwe do it this way
column5: so should you.â€ I think we can help. I know we've got to encourage democracy in the marketplaces. But take Russia
column6: for example. We went into Russia
column7: we said here is some IMF money
column8: and it ended up in Viktor Chemomyrdin's pocket
column9: and others
column10: and yet we played like there was reform. The only people that are going to reform Russia are Russia. They're going to have to make the decision themselves. Mr. Putin is going to have to make the decision as to whether or not he wants to adhere to rule of law and normal accounting practices so that if countries and/or entities invest capital
column11: there's a reasonable rate of return
column12: a way to get the money out of the economy. But Russia has to make the decision. We can work with them on security matters
column13: for example
column14: but it's their call to make. So I'm not exactly sure where the vice president is coming from
column15: but I think one way for us to end up being viewed as the ugly American is for us to go around the world saying
column16: â€œwe do it this way
column17: so should you.â€ Now
column18: we trust freedom. We know freedom is a powerful
column19: powerful
column20: powerful force
column21: much bigger than the United States of America
column22: as we saw recently in the Balkans. But maybe I misunderstand where you're coming from
column23: Mr. Vice President
column24: but I think the United States must be humble and must be proud and confident of our values
column25: but humble in how we treat nations that are figuring out how to chart their own course.

column3: 3)	" I think it's a triumph. I thought the president made the right decision in joining NATO and bombing Serbia. I supported them when they did so. I called upon the Congress not to hamstring the administration
column4: and in terms of forcing troop withdrawals on a timetable that wasn't necessarily in our best interest or fit our nation's strategy
column5: and so I think it's good public policy
column6: I think it worked
column7: and I'm pleased I took -- made the decision I made. I'm pleased the president made the decision he made. Because freedom took hold in that part of the world
column8: but there's a lot of work left to be done
column9: however.

column2: I think it is. Absolutely. I don't think he would have fallen had we not used the force. And I know there are some in our party that disagree with that sentiment. I supported the president. I thought he made the right decision to do so. I didn't think he necessarily made the right decision to take land troops off the table right before we committed ourselves offensively
column3: but nevertheless
column4: it worked. The administration deserves credit for having made it work. It is important for NATO to have it work. It's important for NATO to be strong and confident and to help keep the peace in Europe. And one of the reasons I felt so strongly that the United States needed to participate was because of our relations with NATO
column5: and NATO is going to be an important part of keeping the peace in the future. Now
column6: there's more work to do. Remains to be seen
column7: however
column8: whether or not there's going to be a political settlement in Kosovo
column9: and I certainly hope there is one. Iâ€™m on record as saying at some point in time I hope our European friends become the peacekeepers in Bosnia and in the Balkans. I hope that they put the troops on the ground so that we can withdraw our troops and focus our military on fighting and winning war.

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy
column4: and he's still going to try to be actively involved. He is an indicted war criminal. He should be held accountable. Now
column5: I did want to pick up on one of the statements earlier
column6: and maybe I have heard
column7: maybe I have heard the previous statements wrong
column8: Governor. In some of the discussions we've had about when it's appropriate for the U.S. to use force around the world
column9: at times the standards that you've laid down have given me the impression that if it's something like a genocide taking place or what they called ethnic cleansing in Bosnia
column10: that that alone would not be
column11: that that wouldn't be the kind of situation that would cause you to think that the U.S. ought to get involved with troops. Now
column12: have to be other factors involved for me to want to be involved. But by itself
column13: that to me can bring into play a fundamental American strategic interest because I think it's based on our values. Now
column14: have I got that wrong?

column1: Trying to figure out who the questioner was. If I think it's in our nation's strategic interest I'll commit troops. I thought it was in our strategic interests to keep Milosevic in check because of our relations in NATO
column2: and that's why I took the position I took. I think it's important for NATO to be strong and confident. I felt like unchecked Milosevic would harm NATO
column3: and so it depends on the situation
column4: Mr. Vice President.

column1: Can you run through the list again?
I thought that was a mistake.

column2: I voted for it
column3: supported it.

column5: and I think in retrospect the lessons there are ones that we should take very

column2: yes.

column1: Started off as a humanitarian mission and it changed into a nation-building mission
column2: and that's where the mission went wrong. The mission was changed. And as a result
column3: our nation paid a price. And so I don't think our troops ought to be used for what's called nation-building. I think our troops ought to be used to fight and win war. I think our troops ought to be used to help overthrow the dictator when it's in our best interests. But in this case it was a nation-building exercise
column4: and same with Haiti. I wouldn't have supported either.

column1: Yes. Some of them I've got a conflict of interest on
column2: if you know what I mean.

column1: I think the administration did the right thing in that case. I do. It was a horrible situation
column2: no one liked to see it on our TV screens
column3: but it's a case where we need to make sure we have an early warning system in place in places where there could be ethnic cleansing and genocide the way we saw it there in Rwanda. And that's a case where we need to use our influence to have countries in Africa come together and help deal with the situation. The administration
column4: seems like we're having a great love fest tonight
column5: but the administration made the right decision on training Nigerian troops for situations just such as this in Rwanda
column6: and so I thought they made the right decision not to send U.S. troops into Rwanda.

column1: I'd like to come back to the question of nation building
column2: but let me address the question directly
column3: first. Fine. We did
column4: actually
column5: send troops into Rwanda to help with the humanitarian relief measures. My wife Tipper
column6: who is here
column7: actually went on a military plane with General Sholicatchvieli on one of those flights. But I think in retrospect we were too late getting in there. We could have saved more lives if we had acted earlier. But I do not think that it was an example of a conflict where we should have put our troops in to try to separate the parties for this reason
column8: Jim. One of the criteria that I think is important in deciding when and if we should ever get involved around the world is whether or not our national security interest is involved
column9: if we can really make the difference with military forces. If we tried everything else
column10: if we have allies. In the Balkans we have allies
column11: NATO
column12: ready
column13: willing and able to go and carry a big part of the burden. In Africa we did not. Now
column14: we have tried -- our country has tried to create an Africa crisis response team there
column15: and we've met some resistance. We have had some luck with Nigeria
column16: but in Sierra Leon
column17: and now that Nigeria has become a democracy
column18: and we hope it stays that way
column19: then maybe we can build on that. But because we had no allies and because it was very unclear that we could actually accomplish what we would want to accomplish about putting military forces there
column20: I think it was the right thing not to jump in
column22: but I think we should have come in much quicker with the humanitarian mission.

column2: I understand
column3: and Africa is important. And we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade
column4: and there are some -- Vice President mentioned Nigeria is a fledgling democracy. We have to work with Nigeria. Itâ€™s an important continent. But there's got to be priorities
column5: and Middle East is a priority for a lot of reasons
column6: as is Europe and the Far East
column7: our own hemisphere. And those are my four top priorities should I be the president
column8: not to say we won't be engaged nor work hard to get other nations to come together to prevent atrocity. I thought the best example of a way to handle the situation was East Timor when we provided logistical support to the Australians
column9: support that only we can provide. I thought that was a good model. But we can't be all things to all people in the world
column10: Jim. And I think that's where maybe the vice president and I begin to have some differences. I'm worried about overcommitting our military around the world. I want to be judicious in its use. You mentioned Haiti. I wouldn't have sent troops to Haiti. I didn't think it was a mission worthwhile. It was a nation building mission
column11: and it was not very successful. It cost us billions
column12: a couple billions of dollars
column13: and I'm not so sure democracy is any better off in Haiti than it was before.

column1: I don't think we agree on that. I would certainly also be judicious in evaluating any potential use of American troops overseas. I think we have to be very reticent about that. But look
column2: Jim
column3: the world is changing so rapidly. The way I see it
column4: the world is getting much closer together. Like it or not
column5: we are now -- the United States is now the natural leader of the world. All these other countries are looking to us. Now
column6: just because we cannot be involved everywhere
column7: and shouldn't be
column8: doesn't mean that we should shy away from going in anywhere. Now
column9: both of us are kind of
column10: I guess
column11: stating the other's position in a maximalist extreme way
column12: but I think there is a difference here. This idea of nation building is kind of a pejorative phrase
column13: but think about the great conflict of the past century
column14: World War II. During the years between World War I and World War II
column15: a great lesson was learned by our military leaders and the people of the United States. The lesson was that in the aftermath of World War I
column16: we kind of turned our backs and left them to their own devices and they brewed up a lot of trouble that quickly became World War II. And acting upon that lesson in the aftermath of our great victory in World War II
column17: we laid down the Marshall Plan
column18: President Truman did. We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there. We still have lots of troops in Europe. And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's? We were nation building. And it was economic. But it was also military. And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there. We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.

column1: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said. I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy. And we can't do that. We've got to rebuild our military. But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world. And I mentioned one
column2: and that's the Balkans. I would very much like to get our troops out of there. I recognize we can't do it now
column3: nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground. And there is an example. Haiti is another example. Now there are some places where I think -- you know
column4: I've supported the administration in Columbia. I think it's important for us to be training Columbians in that part of the world. The hemisphere is in our interest to have a peaceful Columbia. But --

column1: I don't think so. I think what we need to do is convince people who live in the lands they live in to build the nations. Maybe I'm missing something here. I mean
column2: we're going to have kind of a nation building core from America? Absolutely not. Our military is meant to fight and win war. That's what it's meant to do. And when it gets overextended
column3: morale drops. I strongly believe we need to have a military presence in the Korean peninsula
column4: not only to keep the peace in the peninsula
column5: but to keep regional stability. And I strongly believe we need to keep a presence in NATO
column6: but I'm going to be judicious as to how to use the military. It needs to be in our vital interest
column7: the mission needs to be clear
column8: and the extra strategy obvious.

column1: I don't disagree with that. I certainly don't disagree that we ought to get our troops home from places like the Balkans as soon as we can
column2: as soon as the mission is complete. That's what we did in Haiti. There are no more than a handful of American military personnel in Haiti now. And Haitians have their problems
column3: but we gave them a chance to restore democracy. That's really about all we can do. But if you have a situation like that right in our backyard with chaos about to break out and flotillas forming to come across the water
column4: and all kinds of violence there
column5: right in one of our neighboring countries there
column6: then I think that we did the right thing there. And as for this idea of nation building
column7: the phrase sounds grandiose. And
column8: you know
column9: we can't be -- we can't allow ourselves to get overextended. I certainly agree with that. And that's why I've supported building up our capacity. I've devoted in the budget I've proposed
column10: as I said last week
column11: more than twice as much as the governor has proposed. I think that it's in better shape now than he generally does. We've had some disagreements about that. He said that two divisions would have to report not ready for duty
column12: and that's not what the joint chiefs say. But there's no doubt that we have to continue building up readiness and military strength. And we have to also be very cautious in the way we use our military.

column2: I mentioned Third World debt.

column1: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way
column2: influence nations. I believe we ought to have foreign aid
column3: but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid. I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform. I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way
column4: and there's some pretty egregious examples recently. One being Russia
column5: where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation. I think the IMF has got a role in the world
column6: but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers
column7: if you make a bad loan
column8: we'll bail you out. It needs to be available for emergency situations. I thought the President did the right thing with Mexico and was very strongly supportive of the administration in Mexico. But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves. So I'll look at every place where we're investing money. I just want to make sure the return is good.

column2: I would make some changes. I think there need to be reforms in the IMF. I've generally supported it
column3: but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable. And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF. The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job
column4: but I think one of the big issues here that doesn't get nearly enough attention is the issue of corruption. The governor mentioned it earlier. I've worked on this issue. It's an enormous problem and corruption in official agencies
column5: like militaries and police departments around the world
column6: customs officials
column7: that's one of the worst forms of it. And we have got to again lead by example and help these other countries that are trying to straighten out their situations find the tools in order to do it. I just think
column8: Jim
column9: that this is an absolutely unique period in world history. The worldâ€™s coming together
column10: as I said
column11: they're looking to us. And we have a fundamental choice to make. Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II
column12: the way that generation of heroes said okay
column13: the United States is going to be the leader. And the world benefitted tremendously from the courage that they showed in those post-war years. I think that in the aftermath of the Cold War
column14: it's time for us to do something very similar
column15: to step up to the plate
column16: to provide the leadership on the environment
column17: leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction. Again
column18: that means not running big deficits here and not squandering our surplus. It means having intelligent decisions that keep our prosperity going and shepherds that economic strength so that we can provide that leadership role.

column1: Let me comment on that. I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be. We can help. And maybe it's just our difference in government
column2: the way we view government. I want to empower the people. I want to help people help themselves
column3: not have government tell people what to do. I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country and say
column4: â€œwe do it this way
column5: so should you.â€ I think we can help. I know we've got to encourage democracy in the marketplaces. But take Russia
column6: for example. We went into Russia
column7: we said here is some IMF money
column8: and it ended up in Viktor Chemomyrdin's pocket
column9: and others
column10: and yet we played like there was reform. The only people that are going to reform Russia are Russia. They're going to have to make the decision themselves. Mr. Putin is going to have to make the decision as to whether or not he wants to adhere to rule of law and normal accounting practices so that if countries and/or entities invest capital
column11: there's a reasonable rate of return
column12: a way to get the money out of the economy. But Russia has to make the decision. We can work with them on security matters
column13: for example
column14: but it's their call to make. So I'm not exactly sure where the vice president is coming from
column15: but I think one way for us to end up being viewed as the ugly American is for us to go around the world saying
column16: â€œwe do it this way
column17: so should you.â€ Now
column18: we trust freedom. We know freedom is a powerful
column19: powerful
column20: powerful force
column21: much bigger than the United States of America
column22: as we saw recently in the Balkans. But maybe I misunderstand where you're coming from
column23: Mr. Vice President
column24: but I think the United States must be humble and must be proud and confident of our values

column3: 3)	" I think it's a triumph. I thought the president made the right decision in joining NATO and bombing Serbia. I supported them when they did so. I called upon the Congress not to hamstring the administration
column4: and in terms of forcing troop withdrawals on a timetable that wasn't necessarily in our best interest or fit our nation's strategy
column5: and so I think it's good public policy
column6: I think it worked
column7: and I'm pleased I took -- made the decision I made. I'm pleased the president made the decision he made. Because freedom took hold in that part of the world
column8: but there's a lot of work left to be done
column9: however.

column2: I think it is. Absolutely. I don't think he would have fallen had we not used the force. And I know there are some in our party that disagree with that sentiment. I supported the president. I thought he made the right decision to do so. I didn't think he necessarily made the right decision to take land troops off the table right before we committed ourselves offensively
column3: but nevertheless
column4: it worked. The administration deserves credit for having made it work. It is important for NATO to have it work. It's important for NATO to be strong and confident and to help keep the peace in Europe. And one of the reasons I felt so strongly that the United States needed to participate was because of our relations with NATO
column5: and NATO is going to be an important part of keeping the peace in the future. Now
column6: there's more work to do. Remains to be seen
column7: however
column8: whether or not there's going to be a political settlement in Kosovo
column9: and I certainly hope there is one. Iâ€™m on record as saying at some point in time I hope our European friends become the peacekeepers in Bosnia and in the Balkans. I hope that they put the troops on the ground so that we can withdraw our troops and focus our military on fighting and winning war.

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy
column4: and he's still going to try to be actively involved. He is an indicted war criminal. He should be held accountable. Now
column5: I did want to pick up on one of the statements earlier
column6: and maybe I have heard
column7: maybe I have heard the previous statements wrong
column8: Governor. In some of the discussions we've had about when it's appropriate for the U.S. to use force around the world
column9: at times the standards that you've laid down have given me the impression that if it's something like a genocide taking place or what they called ethnic cleansing in Bosnia
column10: that that alone would not be
column11: that that wouldn't be the kind of situation that would cause you to think that the U.S. ought to get involved with troops. Now
column12: have to be other factors involved for me to want to be involved. But by itself
column13: that to me can bring into play a fundamental American strategic interest because I think it's based on our values. Now
column14: have I got that wrong?

column1: Trying to figure out who the questioner was. If I think it's in our nation's strategic interest I'll commit troops. I thought it was in our strategic interests to keep Milosevic in check because of our relations in NATO
column2: and that's why I took the position I took. I think it's important for NATO to be strong and confident. I felt like unchecked Milosevic would harm NATO
column3: and so it depends on the situation

I think our troops ought to be used to help overthrow the dictator when it's in our best interests. But in this case it was a nation-building exercise
column4: and same with Haiti. I wouldn't have supported either.

column1: I think the administration did the right thing in that case. I do. It was a horrible situation
column2: no one liked to see it on our TV screens
column3: but it's a case where we need to make sure we have an early warning system in place in places where there could be ethnic cleansing and genocide the way we saw it there in Rwanda. And that's a case where we need to use our influence to have countries in Africa come together and help deal with the situation. The administration
column4: seems like we're having a great love fest tonight
column5: but the administration made the right decision on training Nigerian troops for situations just such as this in Rwanda
column6: and so I thought they made the right decision not to send U.S. troops into Rwanda.

column1: I'd like to come back to the question of nation building
column2: but let me address the question directly
column3: first. Fine. We did
column4: actually
column5: send troops into Rwanda to help with the humanitarian relief measures. My wife Tipper
column6: who is here
column7: actually went on a military plane with General Sholicatchvieli on one of those flights. But I think in retrospect we were too late getting in there. We could have saved more lives if we had acted earlier. But I do not think that it was an example of a conflict where we should have put our troops in to try to separate the parties for this reason
column8: Jim. One of the criteria that I think is important in deciding when and if we should ever get involved around the world is whether or not our national security interest is involved
column9: if we can really make the difference with military forces. If we tried everything else
column10: if we have allies. In the Balkans we have allies
column11: NATO
column12: ready
column13: willing and able to go and carry a big part of the burden. In Africa we did not. Now
column14: we have tried -- our country has tried to create an Africa crisis response team there
column15: and we've met some resistance. We have had some luck with Nigeria
column16: but in Sierra Leon
column17: and now that Nigeria has become a democracy
column18: and we hope it stays that way
column19: then maybe we can build on that. But because we had no allies and because it was very unclear that we could actually accomplish what we would want to accomplish about putting military forces there
column20: I think it was the right thing not to jump in
column22: but I think we should have come in much quicker with the humanitarian mission.

column2: I understand
column3: and Africa is important. And we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade
column4: and there are some -- Vice President mentioned Nigeria is a fledgling democracy. We have to work with Nigeria. Itâ€™s an important continent. But there's got to be priorities
column5: and Middle East is a priority for a lot of reasons
column6: as is Europe and the Far East
column7: our own hemisphere. And those are my four top priorities should I be the president
column8: not to say we won't be engaged nor work hard to get other nations to come together to prevent atrocity. I thought the best example of a way to handle the situation was East Timor when we provided logistical support to the Australians
column9: support that only we can provide. I thought that was a good model. But we can't be all things to all people in the world
column10: Jim. And I think that's where maybe the vice president and I begin to have some differences. I'm worried about overcommitting our military around the world. I want to be judicious in its use. You mentioned Haiti. I wouldn't have sent troops to Haiti. I didn't think it was a mission worthwhile. It was a nation building mission
column11: and it was not very successful. It cost us billions
column12: a couple billions of dollars
column13: and I'm not so sure democracy is any better off in Haiti than it was before.

column1: I don't think we agree on that. I would certainly also be judicious in evaluating any potential use of American troops overseas. I think we have to be very reticent about that. But look
column2: Jim
column3: the world is changing so rapidly. The way I see it
column4: the world is getting much closer together. Like it or not
column5: we are now -- the United States is now the natural leader of the world. All these other countries are looking to us. Now
column6: just because we cannot be involved everywhere
column7: and shouldn't be
column8: doesn't mean that we should shy away from going in anywhere. Now
column9: both of us are kind of
column10: I guess
column11: stating the other's position in a maximalist extreme way
column12: but I think there is a difference here. This idea of nation building is kind of a pejorative phrase
column13: but think about the great conflict of the past century
column14: World War II. During the years between World War I and World War II
column15: a great lesson was learned by our military leaders and the people of the United States. The lesson was that in the aftermath of World War I
column16: we kind of turned our backs and left them to their own devices and they brewed up a lot of trouble that quickly became World War II. And acting upon that lesson in the aftermath of our great victory in World War II
column17: we laid down the Marshall Plan
column18: President Truman did. We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there. We still have lots of troops in Europe. And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's? We were nation building. And it was economic. But it was also military. And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there. We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.

column1: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said. I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy. And we can't do that. We've got to rebuild our military. But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world. And I mentioned one
column2: and that's the Balkans. I would very much like to get our troops out of there. I recognize we can't do it now
column3: nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground. And there is an example. Haiti is another example. Now there are some places where I think -- you know
column4: I've supported the administration in Columbia. I think it's important for us to be training Columbians in that part of the world. The hemisphere is in our interest to have a peaceful Columbia. But --

column1: I don't think so. I think what we need to do is convince people who live in the lands they live in to build the nations. Maybe I'm missing something here. I mean
column2: we're going to have kind of a nation building core from America? Absolutely not. Our military is meant to fight and win war. That's what it's meant to do. And when it gets overextended
column3: morale drops. I strongly believe we need to have a military presence in the Korean peninsula
column4: not only to keep the peace in the peninsula
column5: but to keep regional stability. And I strongly believe we need to keep a presence in NATO
column6: but I'm going to be judicious as to how to use the military. It needs to be in our vital interest
column7: the mission needs to be clear
column8: and the extra strategy obvious.

column1: I don't disagree with that. I certainly don't disagree that we ought to get our troops home from places like the Balkans as soon as we can
column2: as soon as the mission is complete. That's what we did in Haiti. There are no more than a handful of American military personnel in Haiti now. And Haitians have their problems
column3: but we gave them a chance to restore democracy. That's really about all we can do. But if you have a situation like that right in our backyard with chaos about to break out and flotillas forming to come across the water
column4: and all kinds of violence there
column5: right in one of our neighboring countries there
column6: then I think that we did the right thing there. And as for this idea of nation building
column7: the phrase sounds grandiose. And
column8: you know
column9: we can't be -- we can't allow ourselves to get overextended. I certainly agree with that. And that's why I've supported building up our capacity. I've devoted in the budget I've proposed
column10: as I said last week
column11: more than twice as much as the governor has proposed. I think that it's in better shape now than he generally does. We've had some disagreements about that. He said that two divisions would have to report not ready for duty
column12: and that's not what the joint chiefs say. But there's no doubt that we have to continue building up readiness and military strength. And we have to also be very cautious in the way we use our military.

column2: I mentioned Third World debt.

column1: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way
column2: influence nations. I believe we ought to have foreign aid
column3: but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid. I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform. I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way
column4: and there's some pretty egregious examples recently. One being Russia
column5: where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation. I think the IMF has got a role in the world
column6: but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers
column7: if you make a bad loan
column8: we'll bail you out. It needs to be available for emergency situations. I thought the President did the right thing with Mexico and was very strongly supportive of the administration in Mexico. But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves. So I'll look at every place where we're investing money. I just want to make sure the return is good.

column2: I would make some changes. I think there need to be reforms in the IMF. I've generally supported it
column3: but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable. And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF. The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job
column4: but I think one of the big issues here that doesn't get nearly enough attention is the issue of corruption. The governor mentioned it earlier. I've worked on this issue. It's an enormous problem and corruption in official agencies
column5: like militaries and police departments around the world
column6: customs officials
column7: that's one of the worst forms of it. And we have got to again lead by example and help these other countries that are trying to straighten out their situations find the tools in order to do it. I just think
column8: Jim
column9: that this is an absolutely unique period in world history. The worldâ€™s coming together
column10: as I said
column11: they're looking to us. And we have a fundamental choice to make. Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II
column12: the way that generation of heroes said okay
column13: the United States is going to be the leader. And the world benefitted tremendously from the courage that they showed in those post-war years. I think that in the aftermath of the Cold War
column14: it's time for us to do something very similar
column15: to step up to the plate
column16: to provide the leadership on the environment
column17: leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction. Again
column18: that means not running big deficits here and not squandering our surplus. It means having intelligent decisions that keep our prosperity going and shepherds that economic strength so that we can provide that leadership role.

column1: Let me comment on that. I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be. We can help. And maybe it's just our difference in government

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy

column18: President Truman did. We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there. We still have lots of troops in Europe. And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's? We were nation building. And it was economic. But it was also military. And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there. We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.

column1: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said. I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy. And we can't do that. We've got to rebuild our military. But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world. And I mentioned one
column2: and that's the Balkans. I would very much like to get our troops out of there. I recognize we can't do it now
column3: nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal. That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO. No one is suggesting that. Now there are some places where I think -- you know

column1: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way
column2: influence nations. I believe we ought to have foreign aid
column3: but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid. I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform. I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way
column4: and there's some pretty egregious examples recently. One being Russia
column5: where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation. I think the IMF has got a role in the world
column6: but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers

column8: we'll bail you out. It needs to be available for emergency situations. But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves. So I'll look at every place where we're investing money. I just want to make sure the return is good.

column2: I would make some changes. I think there need to be reforms in the IMF. I've generally supported it
column3: but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable. And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF. The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job

column2: I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years. When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic. He caused the death of so many people. He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator. And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics. Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia
column3: and that they question his legitimacy
column4: and he's still going to try to be actively involved. He is an indicted war criminal. He should be held accountable. Now

column14: have I got that wrong?
