column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd
column9: because of Matthew Shepard
column10: who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots
column11: and because of others. And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it
column2: not the Senator Kennedy version. But let me say to you
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: we're happy with our laws on our books. That bill did -- there was another bill that did die in committee. But I want to repeat
column5: if you have a state that fully supports the law like we do in Texas
column6: we're going to go after all crime. And we're going to make sure people get punished for the crime. And in this case we can't enhance the penalty any more than putting those three thugs to death. And that's what's gonna happen in the State of Texas.

column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd
column9: because of Matthew Shepard
column10: who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots
column11: and because of others. And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it
column2: not the Senator Kennedy version. But let me say to you

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it

column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd
column9: because of Matthew Shepard
column10: who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots
column11: and because of others. And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it
column2: not the Senator Kennedy version. But let me say to you
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: we're happy with our laws on our books. That bill did -- there was another bill that did die in committee. But I want to repeat
column5: if you have a state that fully supports the law like we do in Texas
column6: we're going to go after all crime. And we're going to make sure people get punished for the crime. And in this case we can't enhance the penalty any more than putting those three thugs to death. And that's what's gonna happen in the State of Texas.

column321: Phyllis Hunter

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd
column9: because of Matthew Shepard
column10: who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots
column11: and because of others. And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it
column2: not the Senator Kennedy version. But let me say to you
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: we're happy with our laws on our books. That bill did -- there was another bill that did die in committee. But I want to repeat
column5: if you have a state that fully supports the law like we do in Texas
column6: we're going to go after all crime. And we're going to make sure people get punished for the crime. And in this case we can't enhance the penalty any more than putting those three thugs to death. And that's what's gonna happen in the State of Texas.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 4)	" Yes
column4: I would. The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies
column5: but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly
column6: unjustly
column7: and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. Now
column8: that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. And it's not an easy problem to solve. But if I am entrusted with the presidency
column9: it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.

column2: I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed. That's just flat wrong
column3: and that's not what America is all about. And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling. One of my concerns
column4: though
column5: is I don't want to federalize the local police forces. I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law
column6: but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job. I believe in local control of governments
column7: and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level. But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good
column8: dedicated
column9: honorable citizens who are doing their job
column10: putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced. I don't think they ought to be held guilty. But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks
column11: get it done. And if you can't
column12: there will be a federal consequence.

column1: I would agree. And I also agree that most police officers
column2: of course
column3: are doing a good job and hate this practice also. I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield
column4: Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training. And not only the training in police procedures
column5: but human relations. And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America. And as for singling people out because of race
column6: you know
column7: James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas. And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity. And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law. I think these crimes are different. I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred
column8: which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim
column9: but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.

column2: I don't
column3: really.

column1: No. We've got one in Texas. And guess what? The three men who murdered James Byrd
column2: guess what's going to happen to them? They're going to be put to death. A jury found them guilty. It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death. And it's the right cause. It's the right decision. Secondly
column3: there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America. Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence. People are stopped
column4: and we have to do something about that. My friend
column5: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan
column6: is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect. So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces. It's an issue throughout our society. And as we become a diverse society
column7: we're going to have to deal with it more and more. I believe
column8: though -- I believe
column9: as sure as I'm sitting here
column10: that most Americans really care. They're tolerant people. They're good
column11: tolerant people. It's the very few that create most of the crises
column12: and we just have to find them and deal with them.

column1: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes. In public education when we just move children through the schools. My friend
column2: Phyllis Hunter
column3: is here. She had one of the greatest lines of all lines. She said
column4: reading is the new civil right. She's right. And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be
column5: every single child in America must be educated. I mean every child. It starts with making sure every child learns to read. K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency. Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum. Intensive reading laboratories
column6: teacher retraining. I mean
column7: there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling
column8: which is illiterate children. We can do better in our public schools. We can close an achievement gap
column9: and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability
column10: Jim. One of the cornerstones of reform
column11: and good reform
column12: is to measure. Because when you measure you can ask the question
column13: do they know? Is anybody being profiled? Is anybody being discriminated against? It becomes a tool
column14: a corrective tool. And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money
column15: any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children
column16: for example
column17: you must show us whether or not the children are learning. And if they are
column18: fine. And if they're not
column19: there has to be a consequence. And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education. There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.

column2: I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws. I think we still need affirmative action. I would pass a hate crimes law
column3: as I said
column4: and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position. The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also. But I would like to shift
column5: if I could
column6: to the big issue of education.

column2: I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed
column3: and that the Byrd family
column4: among others
column5: asked you to support it
column6: Governor
column7: and it died in committee for lack of support. Am I wrong about that?

column2: you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute? We do.

column1: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --

column2: what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas. And secondly
column3: the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment. The death penalty.

column1: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate
column2: Jim. The crime is hate. And they got the ultimate punishment. I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty. We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.

column1: I don't want to jump in. I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter
column2: because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did
column3: in fact
column4: die in committee. There may be some other statute that was already on the books
column5: but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed. And it's important
column6: Jim
column7: not only -- not just because of Texas
column8: but because this mirrors the national controversy. There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd
column9: because of Matthew Shepard
column10: who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots
column11: and because of others. And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.

column1: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it
column2: not the Senator Kennedy version. But let me say to you
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: we're happy with our laws on our books. That bill did -- there was another bill that did die in committee. But I want to repeat
column5: if you have a state that fully supports the law like we do in Texas
column6: we're going to go after all crime. And we're going to make sure people get punished for the crime. And in this case we can't enhance the penalty any more than putting those three thugs to death. And that's what's gonna happen in the State of Texas.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 5)	" I'm not for gay marriage. I think marriage is a sacred institution between a man and a woman. And I appreciated the way the administration signed the Defense of Marriage Act. I presume the Vice President supported it when the President signed that bill and supports it now. But I think marriage is a sacred institution. I'm going to be respectful for people who may disagree with me. I've had a record of doing so in the State of Texas. I've been a person that had been called a uniter
column4: not a divider
column5: because I accept other people's points of view. But I feel strongly that marriage should be between a man and a woman.

column2: and I did support that law. But I think that we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions
column3: and I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman. And I think the three of us have one view and the Governor has another view.

column1: I'm not sure what kind of view he's describing to me. I can just tell you
column2: I'm a person who respects other people. I respect their -- I respect -- on the one hand he says he agrees with me and then he says he doesn't. I'm not sure where he's coming from. But I will be a tolerant person. I've been a tolerant person all my life. I just happen to believe strongly that marriage is between a man and a woman.

column1: Yes. I don't think they ought to have special rights
column2: but I think they ought to have the same rights.

there's a law pending called the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. I strongly support it. What it says is that gays and lesbians can't be fired from their job because they're gay or lesbian. And it would be a federal law preventing that. Now
column3: I wonder if the -- it's been blocked by the opponents in the majority in the Congress. I wonder if the Governor would lend his support to that law.

column2: I have no idea. I mean
column3: he can throw out all kinds -- I don't know the particulars of this law. I will tell you I'm the kind of person
column4: I don't hire or fire somebody based upon their sexual orientation. As a matter of fact
column5: I would like to take the issue a little further. I don't really think it's any of my -- you know
column6: any of my concerns what -- how you conduct your sex life. And I think that's a private matter. And I think that's the way it ought to be. But I'm going to be respectful for people
column7: I'll tolerate people
column8: and I support equal rights but not special rights for people.

column2: it would be if they're given special protective status. That doesn't mean we shouldn't fully enforce laws and fully protect people and fully honor people
column3: which I will do as the President of the United States.

column1: But I think that we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions, and I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman. column2: '11Oct'
column3: 5)	" I'm not for gay marriage. I think marriage is a sacred institution between a man and a woman. And I appreciated the way the administration signed the Defense of Marriage Act. I presume the Vice President supported it when the President signed that bill and supports it now. But I think marriage is a sacred institution. I'm going to be respectful for people who may disagree with me. I've had a record of doing so in the State of Texas. I've been a person that had been called a uniter
column4: not a divider
column5: because I accept other people's points of view. But I feel strongly that marriage should be between a man and a woman.

column2: and I did support that law. But I think that we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions
column3: and I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman. And I think the three of us have one view and the Governor has another view.

column1: I'm not sure what kind of view he's describing to me. I can just tell you
column2: I'm a person who respects other people. I respect their -- I respect -- on the one hand he says he agrees with me and then he says he doesn't. I'm not sure where he's coming from. But I will be a tolerant person. I've been a tolerant person all my life. I just happen to believe strongly that marriage is between a man and a woman.

column1: Yes. I don't think they ought to have special rights
column2: but I think they ought to have the same rights.

there's a law pending called the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. I strongly support it. What it says is that gays and lesbians can't be fired from their job because they're gay or lesbian. And it would be a federal law preventing that. Now
column3: I wonder if the -- it's been blocked by the opponents in the majority in the Congress. I wonder if the Governor would lend his support to that law.

column2: I have no idea. I mean
column3: he can throw out all kinds -- I don't know the particulars of this law. I will tell you I'm the kind of person
column4: I don't hire or fire somebody based upon their sexual orientation. As a matter of fact
column5: I would like to take the issue a little further. I don't really think it's any of my -- you know
column6: any of my concerns what -- how you conduct your sex life. And I think that's a private matter. And I think that's the way it ought to be. But I'm going to be respectful for people
column7: I'll tolerate people
column8: and I support equal rights but not special rights for people.

column2: it would be if they're given special protective status. That doesn't mean we shouldn't fully enforce laws and fully protect people and fully honor people
column3: which I will do as the President of the United States.

column1: But I think that we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions, and I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman.
