column2: '11Oct'
column3: 6)	" Jim
column4: I hope that we can come back to the subject of education because the governor made an extensive statement on it and I have a very different view than the one he expressed. But that having been said
column5: I believe that -- well
column6: first of all
column7: let me say that the governor and I agree on some things where this subject is concerned. I will not do anything to affect the rights of hunters or sportsmen. I think that homeowners have to be respected and their right to have a gun if they wish to. The problem I see is that there are too many guns getting into the hands of children
column8: and criminals
column9: and people who
column10: for whatever reason
column11: some kind of history of stalking or domestic abuse really should not be able to get guns. I think these assault weapons are a problem. So I favor closing the gun show loophole. In fact
column12: I cast the tie-breaking vote to close it
column13: but then the majority in the House of Representatives went the other way. That's still pending. If we could get agreement on that
column14: maybe they could pass that in the final days of this Congress. I think we ought to restore the three-day waiting period under the Brady Law. I think we should toughen the enforcement of gun laws so that the ones that are already on the books can be enforced much more effectively. Some of the restrictions that have been placed by the Congress in the last couple of years. I think -- in the last few years I think have been unfortunate. I think that we ought to make all schools gun free. Have a gun-free zone around every school in this country. I think that measures like these are important. Child safety trigger locks on a mandatory basis
column15: and others.

column2: it starts with enforcing law. When you say loud and clear to somebody if you're going to carry a gun illegally
column3: we're going to arrest you. If you're going to sell a gun illegally
column4: you need to be arrested. If you commit a crime with a gun
column5: there needs to be absolute certainty in the law. And that means that the local law enforcement officials need help at the federal level. Programs like Project Exile where the federal government intensifies arresting people who illegally use guns. And we haven't done a very good job of that at the federal level recently. And I'm going to make it a priority. Secondly
column6: I don't think we ought to be selling guns to people who shouldn't have them. That's why I support instant background checks at gun shows. One of the reasons we have an instant background check is so that we instantly know whether or not somebody should have a gun or not. In Texas I tried to do something innovative. There's a lot of talk about trigger locks being on guns sold in the future. I support that. But I said if you want a trigger lock to make your gun safe
column7: come and get one for free. So we're distributing in our State of Texas for free. I think we ought to raise the age at which a juvenile can carry a handgun from 18 to 21. I disagree with the vice president on this issue. He is for registration of guns. I think the only people that are going to show up to register or get a license -- I guess licensing like a driver's license for a gun
column8: the only people that are going to show up are law-abiding citizens. The criminal is not going to show up and say hey
column9: give me my I.D. card. It's the law-abiding citizens who will do that. An I don't think that is going to be an effective tool to make the -- keep our society safe.

column2: I'm not for registration. I am for licensing by states of new handgun purchases.

column1: A photo license I.D. like a driver's license for new handguns and
column2: you know
column3: the Los Angeles --

column1: The state. The state. I think states should do that for new handguns
column2: because too many criminals are getting guns. There was a recent investigation of the number in Texas who got -- who were given concealed weapons permits in spite of the fact that they had records. And the ""Los Angeles Times"" spent a lot of ink going into that. But I am not for doing anything that would affect hunters or sportsmen
column3: rifles
column4: shotguns
column5: existing handguns. I do think that sensible gun safety measures are warranted now. Look
column6: this is the year -- this is in the aftermath of Columbine
column7: and Paducah
column8: and all the places in our country where the nation has been shocked by these weapons in the hands of the wrong people. The woman who bought the guns for the two boys who did that killing at Columbine said that if she had had to give her name and fill out a form there
column9: she would not have bought those guns. That conceivably could have prevented that tragedy.

column2: I'm not for photo licensing. Let me say something about Columbine. Listen
column3: we've got gun laws. He says we ought to have gun-free schools. Everybody believes that. I'm sure every state in the union has got them. You can't carry a gun into a school. And there ought to be a consequence when you do carry a gun into a school. But Columbine spoke to a larger issue. It's really a matter of culture. It's a culture that somewhere along the line we've begun to disrespect life. Where a child can walk in and have their heart turned dark as a result of being on the Internet and walk in and decide to take somebody else's life? So gun laws are important
column4: no question about it
column5: but so is loving children
column6: and character education classes
column7: and faith-based programs being a part of after-school programs. Some desperate child needs to have somebody put their arm around them and say
column8: we love you. So there's a -- this is a society that -- of ours that's got to do a better job of teaching children right from wrong. And we can enforce law. But there seems to be a lot of preoccupation on -- not certainly only in this debate
column9: but just in general on law. But there's a larger law. Love your neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. And that's where our society must head if we're going to be a peaceful and prosperous society.

column1: I also believe in the Golden Rule. And I agree with a lot of the other things that the governor has said. We do have a serious problem in our culture. Tipper and I have worked on the problem of violence in entertainment aimed at children. She's worked on it longer than I have. But I feel very strongly about that. And if I'm elected president
column2: I will do something about that. But I think that we -- I think we have to start with better parenting. But I don't think that we can ignore the role played by guns. I mean
column3: the fact is that there -- even though no state wants them
column4: there are guns in some schools. And the reason it's so difficult for schools to control that is because in recent years there has been a flood of cheap handguns that are so widely available that kids are finding ways to get ahold of them. And I think that if you look at the situation as it exists here in the United States compared to any other country in the world
column5: it seems to me pretty obvious that while we respect the rights of hunters and sportsmen
column6: we do need some common sense gun safety steps to stem this flood of guns that are getting into the wrong hands.

column2: no question about that
column3: but there also needs to be strong enforcement of the law. Some kid who feels like -- doesn't matter where the gun comes from
column4: it could be a cheap gun
column5: expensive gun. What matters is something in this person's head says there is not going to be a consequence. So in my state we toughen up the juvenile justice laws. We added beds. We're tough. We believe in tough love. We say
column6: if you get caught carrying a gun
column7: you're automatically detained. And that's what needs to happen. We've got laws. If laws need to be strengthened
column8: like instant background checks
column9: that's important.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 6)	" Jim
column4: I hope that we can come back to the subject of education because the governor made an extensive statement on it and I have a very different view than the one he expressed. But that having been said
column5: I believe that -- well
column6: first of all
column7: let me say that the governor and I agree on some things where this subject is concerned. I will not do anything to affect the rights of hunters or sportsmen. I think that homeowners have to be respected and their right to have a gun if they wish to. The problem I see is that there are too many guns getting into the hands of children
column8: and criminals
column9: and people who
column10: for whatever reason
column11: some kind of history of stalking or domestic abuse really should not be able to get guns. I think these assault weapons are a problem. So I favor closing the gun show loophole. In fact
column12: I cast the tie-breaking vote to close it
column13: but then the majority in the House of Representatives went the other way. That's still pending. If we could get agreement on that
column14: maybe they could pass that in the final days of this Congress. I think we ought to restore the three-day waiting period under the Brady Law. I think we should toughen the enforcement of gun laws so that the ones that are already on the books can be enforced much more effectively. Some of the restrictions that have been placed by the Congress in the last couple of years. I think -- in the last few years I think have been unfortunate. I think that we ought to make all schools gun free. Have a gun-free zone around every school in this country. I think that measures like these are important. Child safety trigger locks on a mandatory basis
column15: and others.

column2: it starts with enforcing law. When you say loud and clear to somebody if you're going to carry a gun illegally
column3: we're going to arrest you. If you're going to sell a gun illegally
column4: you need to be arrested. If you commit a crime with a gun
column5: there needs to be absolute certainty in the law. And that means that the local law enforcement officials need help at the federal level. Programs like Project Exile where the federal government intensifies arresting people who illegally use guns. And we haven't done a very good job of that at the federal level recently. And I'm going to make it a priority. Secondly
column6: I don't think we ought to be selling guns to people who shouldn't have them. That's why I support instant background checks at gun shows. One of the reasons we have an instant background check is so that we instantly know whether or not somebody should have a gun or not. In Texas I tried to do something innovative. There's a lot of talk about trigger locks being on guns sold in the future. I support that. But I said if you want a trigger lock to make your gun safe
column7: come and get one for free. So we're distributing in our State of Texas for free. I think we ought to raise the age at which a juvenile can carry a handgun from 18 to 21. I disagree with the vice president on this issue. He is for registration of guns. I think the only people that are going to show up to register or get a license -- I guess licensing like a driver's license for a gun
column8: the only people that are going to show up are law-abiding citizens. The criminal is not going to show up and say hey
column9: give me my I.D. card. It's the law-abiding citizens who will do that. An I don't think that is going to be an effective tool to make the -- keep our society safe.

column2: I'm not for registration. I am for licensing by states of new handgun purchases.

column1: A photo license I.D. like a driver's license for new handguns and
column2: you know
column3: the Los Angeles --

column1: The state. The state. I think states should do that for new handguns
column2: because too many criminals are getting guns. There was a recent investigation of the number in Texas who got -- who were given concealed weapons permits in spite of the fact that they had records. And the ""Los Angeles Times"" spent a lot of ink going into that. But I am not for doing anything that would affect hunters or sportsmen
column3: rifles
column4: shotguns
column5: existing handguns. I do think that sensible gun safety measures are warranted now. Look
column6: this is the year -- this is in the aftermath of Columbine
column7: and Paducah
column8: and all the places in our country where the nation has been shocked by these weapons in the hands of the wrong people. The woman who bought the guns for the two boys who did that killing at Columbine said that if she had had to give her name and fill out a form there
column9: she would not have bought those guns. That conceivably could have prevented that tragedy.

column2: I'm not for photo licensing. Let me say something about Columbine. Listen
column3: we've got gun laws. He says we ought to have gun-free schools. Everybody believes that. I'm sure every state in the union has got them. You can't carry a gun into a school. And there ought to be a consequence when you do carry a gun into a school. But Columbine spoke to a larger issue. It's really a matter of culture. It's a culture that somewhere along the line we've begun to disrespect life. Where a child can walk in and have their heart turned dark as a result of being on the Internet and walk in and decide to take somebody else's life? So gun laws are important
column4: no question about it
column5: but so is loving children
column6: and character education classes
column7: and faith-based programs being a part of after-school programs. Some desperate child needs to have somebody put their arm around them and say
column8: we love you. So there's a -- this is a society that -- of ours that's got to do a better job of teaching children right from wrong. And we can enforce law. But there seems to be a lot of preoccupation on -- not certainly only in this debate
column9: but just in general on law. But there's a larger law. Love your neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself. And that's where our society must head if we're going to be a peaceful and prosperous society.

column1: I also believe in the Golden Rule. And I agree with a lot of the other things that the governor has said. We do have a serious problem in our culture. Tipper and I have worked on the problem of violence in entertainment aimed at children. She's worked on it longer than I have. But I feel very strongly about that. And if I'm elected president
column2: I will do something about that. But I think that we -- I think we have to start with better parenting. But I don't think that we can ignore the role played by guns. I mean
column3: the fact is that there -- even though no state wants them
column4: there are guns in some schools. And the reason it's so difficult for schools to control that is because in recent years there has been a flood of cheap handguns that are so widely available that kids are finding ways to get ahold of them. And I think that if you look at the situation as it exists here in the United States compared to any other country in the world
column5: it seems to me pretty obvious that while we respect the rights of hunters and sportsmen
column6: we do need some common sense gun safety steps to stem this flood of guns that are getting into the wrong hands.

column2: no question about that
column3: but there also needs to be strong enforcement of the law. Some kid who feels like -- doesn't matter where the gun comes from
column4: it could be a cheap gun
column5: expensive gun. What matters is something in this person's head says there is not going to be a consequence. So in my state we toughen up the juvenile justice laws. We added beds. We're tough. We believe in tough love. We say
column6: if you get caught carrying a gun
column7: you're automatically detained. And that's what needs to happen. We've got laws. If laws need to be strengthened
column8: like instant background checks
column9: that's important.

column2: I hope that we can come back to the subject of education because the governor made an extensive statement on it and I have a very different view than the one he expressed.'
column3: 'But that having been said
column4: I believe that -- well
column5: first of all
column6: let me say that the governor and I agree on some things where this subject is concerned.'
column7: 'I will not do anything to affect the rights of hunters or sportsmen.'
column8: 'I think that homeowners have to be respected and their right to have a gun if they wish to.'
column9: 'The problem I see is that there are too many guns getting into the hands of children
column10: and criminals
column11: and people who
column12: for whatever reason
column13: some kind of history of stalking or domestic abuse really should not be able to get guns.'
column14: 'I think these assault weapons are a problem.'
column15: 'So I favor closing the gun show loophole.'
column16: 'In fact
column17: I cast the tie-breaking vote to close it
column18: but then the majority in the House of Representatives went the other way.'
column19: ""That's still pending.""
column20: 'If we could get agreement on that
column21: maybe they could pass that in the final days of this Congress.'
column22: 'I think we ought to restore the three-day waiting period under the Brady Law.'
column23: 'I think we should toughen the enforcement of gun laws so that the ones that are already on the books can be enforced much more effectively.'
column24: 'Some of the restrictions that have been placed by the Congress in the last couple of years.'
column25: 'I think -- in the last few years I think have been unfortunate.'
column26: 'I think that we ought to make all schools gun free.'
column27: 'Have a gun-free zone around every school in this country.'
column28: 'I think that measures like these are important.'
column29: 'Child safety trigger locks on a mandatory basis
column30: and others.'
column31: 'Well
column32: it starts with enforcing law.'
column33: ""When you say loud and clear to somebody if you're going to carry a gun illegally

column37: 'If you commit a crime with a gun
column38: there needs to be absolute certainty in the law.'
column39: 'And that means that the local law enforcement officials need help at the federal level.'

column41: ""And we haven't done a very good job of that at the federal level recently.""
column42: ""And I'm going to make it a priority.""
column44: I don't think we ought to be selling guns to people who shouldn't have them.""
column45: ""That's why I support instant background checks at gun shows.""
column46: 'One of the reasons we have an instant background check is so that we instantly know whether or not somebody should have a gun or not.'
column47: 'In Texas I tried to do something innovative.'
column48: ""There's a lot of talk about trigger locks being on guns sold in the future.""
column49: 'I support that.'

column51: come and get one for free.'
column52: ""So we're distributing in our State of Texas for free.""
column53: 'I think we ought to raise the age at which a juvenile can carry a handgun from 18 to 21.'
column54: 'I disagree with the vice president on this issue.'
column55: 'He is for registration of guns.'
column56: ""I think the only people that are going to show up to register or get a license -- I guess licensing like a driver's license for a gun
column57: the only people that are going to show up are law-abiding citizens.""
column58: 'The criminal is not going to show up and say hey
column59: give me my I.D.'
column61: ""It's the law-abiding citizens who will do that.""
column62: ""An I don't think that is going to be an effective tool to make the -- keep our society safe.""

column83: this is the year -- this is in the aftermath of Columbine
column85: and all the places in our country where the nation has been shocked by these weapons in the hands of the wrong people.'

column91: 'Let me say something about Columbine.'

column102: ""Where a child can walk in and have their heart turned dark as a result of being on the Internet and walk in and decide to take somebody else's life?""
column103: 'So gun laws are important

column114: ""But there's a larger law.""

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column1: And my case to the American people is, if you're happy with inactivity, stay with the horse. column2: '11Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history

column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.
