column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: I've got a plan to do something about that. It's to make health care affordable and available this way. First
column5: there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to. There's some --

column2: healthy young kids say I'll never get sick
column3: therefore I don't need health care right now. For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest
column4: like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity. In other words
column5: you say to a youngster
column6: it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness
column7: but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it
column8: a couple of things we need to do. One
column9: we need more community health centers. I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country. These are places where people can get primary care. Secondly -- and they're good. They're very important parts of the safety net of health care. Secondly
column10: that you get a $2
column11: 000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30
column12: 000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets. It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system. If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it
column13: the pool purchasing power. And to make health care more affordable
column14: allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down. I think that's the very best way to go. It empowers people
column15: it trusts people
column16: it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.

column1: It's one of my top priorities
column2: Jim
column3: to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years. I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care
column4: but I'm not for a government-run system. In fact
column5: I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government. I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300
column6: 000 people in the last several years. And the budget plan that I've put out
column7: according to the ""Los Angeles Times"" again
column8: the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP
column9: will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people. But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country. I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance. So it's one of my top priorities. Now
column10: I know that we have some disagreements on this. And I'm sorry to tell you that
column11: you know
column12: there is a record here. And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care. 49th for women with health care
column13: and 50th for families with health care. So it is a priority for me. I guarantee you. I'm not aware of any program -- well
column14: I'll just leave it at that. I think it ought to be a top priority.

column2: let me say he's not for a government-run health care system? I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system. It was fortunately stopped in its tracks. Secondly
column3: we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas. Our rate of uninsured
column4: the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down
column5: while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up. Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years
column6: Mr. Vice President. It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long. But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union. And therefore Congress passes the bill after our session in 1997 ended
column7: we passed an enabling legislation in 1999. We've signed up over 110
column8: 000 children to the CHIPS program. For comparable states our size
column9: we're signing them up as fast as any other state. You can quote all the numbers you want
column10: but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas. We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas
column11: and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

column2: I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out
column3: but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right
column4: the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women
column5: is because those facts are correct. And as for why it happened
column6: I'm no expert on the Texas procedures
column7: but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered. And instead directed the money toward a tax cut
column8: a significant part of which went to wealthy interests. He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need
column9: and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program. There's -- you don't have to take my word for this. There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this. I believe there are 1.4 million children in Texas who do not have health insurance. 600
column10: 000 of whom
column11: and maybe some of those have since gotten it
column12: but as of a year ago 600
column13: 000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.

column1: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children
column2: he's absolutely wrong. We've spent $4.7 billion a year in the State of Texas for uninsured people. And they get health care. Now
column3: it's not the most efficient way to get people health care. But I want to remind you
column4: the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased. He can make any excuse he wants
column5: but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population. And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally
column6: somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd. Let me just tell you who the jury is. The people of Texas. There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms
column7: and that was me. And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes
column8: nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote
column9: about 27% of the African-American vote
column10: because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person. So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around. I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right. We come together both Republicans and Democrats.

column2: yes. But it's not a statement about his heart. I don't claim to know his heart. I think he's a good person. I make no allegations about that. I believe him when he says that he has a good heart. I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person. But I think it's about his priorities. And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean
column3: if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families
column4: and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history
column5: wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to
column6: say
column7: 45 or 40 or something or maybe better? I would. Now
column8: but here is why it's directly relevant
column9: Jim. Because by his own budget numbers
column10: his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined. According to his own numbers. So it's not a question of his heart
column11: as far as I know. It's a question of priorities and values. See
column12: you know --

column2: that's simply not true what he just said
column3: of course. And secondly
column4: I repeat to you --

column1: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending. The top -- let's talk about my tax plan. The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. And in return
column2: get one-fifth of the benefits
column3: because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. That stands in stark contrast
column4: by the way
column5: to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. We just have a different point of view. It's a totally different point of view. He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. Let me go back to Texas
column6: for example
column7: for a minute. We pay 4.7 billion. I can't emphasize to you how much. I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session. We're working hard to sign up children. We're doing it faster than any other state our size
column8: comparable state. We're making really good progress. And our state cares a lot about our children. My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington
column9: D.C. on the uninsured. They have not done it. They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. And they have not got it done. And my case to the American people is
column10: if you're happy with inactivity
column11: stay with the horse. The horse is up here now. But if you want change
column12: you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 8)	" I do. I think that in this 21st century we will soon see the consequences of what's called global warming. There was a study just a few weeks ago suggesting that in summertime the north polar ice cap will be completely gone in 50 years. Already many people see the strange weather conditions that the old timers say they've never seen before in their lifetimes. And what's happening is the level of pollution is increasing significantly. Now
column4: here is the good news
column5: Jim. If we take the leadership role and build the new technologies
column6: like the new kinds of cars and trucks that Detroit is itching to build
column7: then we can create millions of good new jobs by being first into the market with these new kinds of cars and trucks and other kinds of technologies. You know the Japanese are breathing down our necks on this. They're moving very rapidly because they know that it is a fast-growing world market. Some of these other countries
column8: particularly in the developing world
column9: their pollution is much worse than anywhere else and their people want higher standards of living. And so they're looking for ways to satisfy their desire for a better life and still reduce pollution at the same time. I think that holding onto the old ways and the old argument that the environment and the economy are in conflict is really outdated. We have to be bold. We have to provide leadership. Now it's true that we disagree on this. The governor said that he doesn't think this problem is necessarily caused by people. He's for letting the oil companies into the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Houston has just become the smoggiest city in the country. And Texas is number one in industrial pollution. We have a very different outlook. And I'll tell you this
column10: I will fight for a clean environment in ways that strengthen our economy.

column2: let me start with Texas. We are a big industrial state. We reduced our industrial waste by 11%. We cleaned up more brown fields than any other administration in my state's history
column3: 450 of them. Our water is cleaner now.

column1: A brown field is an abandoned industrial site that just sits idle in some of our urban centers. And people are willing to invest capital in the brown fields don't want to do so for fear of lawsuit. I think we ought to have federal liability protection
column2: depending upon whether or not standards have been met. The book you mentioned that Vice President Gore wrote
column3: he also called for taxing -- big energy taxes in order to clean up the environment. And now that the energy prices are high
column4: I guess he's not advocating those big energy taxes right now. I believe we ought to fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund to -- with half the money going to states so states can make the right decisions for environmental quality. I think we need to have clean coal technologies. I propose $2 billion worth. By the way
column5: I just found out the other day an interesting fact
column6: that there is a national petroleum reserve right next to -- in Prudhoe Bay that your administration opened up for exploration in that pristine area. And it was a smart move because there's gas reserves up there. We need gas pipelines to bring the gas down. Gas is a clean fuel that we can burn to -- we need to make sure that if we decontrol our plants that there's mandatory -- that the plants must conform to clean air standards
column7: the grandfathered plants
column8: that's what we did in Texas. No excuses. You must conform. In other words
column9: there are practical things we can do. But it starts with working in a collaborative effort with states and local folks. If you own the land
column10: every day is Earth Day. People care a lot about their land and care about their environment. Not all wisdom is in Washington
column11: D.C. on this issue.

column1: I'm really strongly committed to clean water and clean air
column2: and cleaning up the new kinds of challenges like global warming. He is right that I'm not in favor of energy taxes. I am in favor of tax cuts to encourage and give incentives for the quicker development of these new kinds of technologies. And let me say again
column3: Detroit is rearing to go on that. We differ on the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge
column4: as I have said. We differ on whether or not pollution controls ought to be voluntary. I don't think you can -- I don't think you can get results that way. We differ on the kinds of appointments that we would make.

column1: I think it's a fundamental difference. Let me give you an example.

column2: sure.
I don't believe in command and control out of Washington
column3: D.C. I believe Washington ought to set standards
column4: but again I think we ought to be collaborative at the local levels and I think we ought to work with people at the local levels. And by the way
column5: I just want to make sure -- I can't let him just say something and not correct it. The electric decontrol bill that I fought for and signed in Texas has mandatory emission standards
column6: Mr. Vice President. That's what we ought to do at the federal level when it comes to grandfathered plants for utilities. I think there's a difference. I think
column7: for example
column8: take -- when they took 40 million acres of land out of circulation without consulting local officials
column9: I thought that was --

column2: yeah. And so -- on the logging issue. That's not the way I would have done it. Perhaps some of that land needs to be set aside. But I certainly would have consulted with governors and elected officials before I would have acted unilaterally.
absolutely
column3: so long as they're based upon science and they're reasonable. So long as people have input.

column1: I think it's an issue that we need to take very seriously. But I don't think we know the solution to global warming yet. And I don't think we've got all the facts before we make decisions. I tell you one thing I'm not going to do is I'm not going to let the United States carry the burden for cleaning up the world's air. Like Kyoto Treaty would have done. China and India were exempted from that treaty. I think we need to be more even-handed
column2: as evidently 99 senators -- I think it was 99 senators supported that position.

that vote wasn't exactly -- a lot of the supporters of the Kyoto Treaty actually ended up voting for that because the way it was worded. But there's no doubt there's a lot of opposition to it in the Senate. I'm not for command and control techniques either. I'm for working with the groups
column3: not just with industry but also with the citizen groups and local communities to control sprawl in ways that the local communities themselves come up with. But I disagree that we don't know the cause of global warming. I think that we do. It's pollution
column4: carbon dioxide
column5: and other chemicals that are even more potent
column6: but in smaller quantities
column7: that cause this. Look
column8: the world's temperature is going up
column9: weather patterns are changing
column10: storms are getting more violent and unpredictable. What are we going to tell our children? I'm a grandfather now. I want to be able to tell my grandson when I'm in my later years that I didn't turn away from the evidence that showed that we were doing some serious harm. In my faith tradition
column11: it is -- it's written in the book of Matthew
column12: ""Where your heart is
column13: there is your treasure also."" And I believe that -- that we ought to recognize the value to our children and grandchildren of taking steps that preserve the environment in a way that's good for them.

column2: I agree. I just -- I think there has been -- some of the scientists
column3: I believe
column4: Mr. Vice President
column5: haven't they been changing their opinion a little bit on global warming? A profound scientist recently made a different --

column1: I've been trying so hard not to.

column2: by the way.
Mr. Vice President.

column1: Of course they care about them. Oh
column2: you mean the rules.

column1: What the heck. I -- of course there's a lot -- look
column2: global warming needs to be taken very seriously
column3: and I take it seriously. But science
column4: there's a lot -- there's differing opinions. And before we react
column5: I think it's best to have the full accounting
column6: full understanding of what's taking place. And I think to answer your question
column7: I think both of us care a lot about the environment. We may have different approaches. We may have different approaches in terms of how we deal with local folks. I just cited an example of the administration just unilaterally acting without any input. And I remember you gave a very good answer to New Hampshire about the White Mountains
column8: about how it was important to keep that collaborative effort in place. I feel very strongly the same place. It certainly wasn't the attitude that took place out west
column9: however.

column2: '11Oct'
column3: 8)	" I do. I think that in this 21st century we will soon see the consequences of what's called global warming. There was a study just a few weeks ago suggesting that in summertime the north polar ice cap will be completely gone in 50 years. Already many people see the strange weather conditions that the old timers say they've never seen before in their lifetimes. And what's happening is the level of pollution is increasing significantly. Now
column4: here is the good news
column5: Jim. If we take the leadership role and build the new technologies
column6: like the new kinds of cars and trucks that Detroit is itching to build
column7: then we can create millions of good new jobs by being first into the market with these new kinds of cars and trucks and other kinds of technologies. You know the Japanese are breathing down our necks on this. They're moving very rapidly because they know that it is a fast-growing world market. Some of these other countries
column8: particularly in the developing world
column9: their pollution is much worse than anywhere else and their people want higher standards of living. And so they're looking for ways to satisfy their desire for a better life and still reduce pollution at the same time. I think that holding onto the old ways and the old argument that the environment and the economy are in conflict is really outdated. We have to be bold. We have to provide leadership. Now it's true that we disagree on this. The governor said that he doesn't think this problem is necessarily caused by people. He's for letting the oil companies into the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Houston has just become the smoggiest city in the country. And Texas is number one in industrial pollution. We have a very different outlook. And I'll tell you this
column10: I will fight for a clean environment in ways that strengthen our economy.

column2: let me start with Texas. We are a big industrial state. We reduced our industrial waste by 11%. We cleaned up more brown fields than any other administration in my state's history
column3: 450 of them. Our water is cleaner now.

column1: A brown field is an abandoned industrial site that just sits idle in some of our urban centers. And people are willing to invest capital in the brown fields don't want to do so for fear of lawsuit. I think we ought to have federal liability protection
column2: depending upon whether or not standards have been met. The book you mentioned that Vice President Gore wrote
column3: he also called for taxing -- big energy taxes in order to clean up the environment. And now that the energy prices are high
column4: I guess he's not advocating those big energy taxes right now. I believe we ought to fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund to -- with half the money going to states so states can make the right decisions for environmental quality. I think we need to have clean coal technologies. I propose $2 billion worth. By the way
column5: I just found out the other day an interesting fact
column6: that there is a national petroleum reserve right next to -- in Prudhoe Bay that your administration opened up for exploration in that pristine area. And it was a smart move because there's gas reserves up there. We need gas pipelines to bring the gas down. Gas is a clean fuel that we can burn to -- we need to make sure that if we decontrol our plants that there's mandatory -- that the plants must conform to clean air standards
column7: the grandfathered plants
column8: that's what we did in Texas. No excuses. You must conform. In other words
column9: there are practical things we can do. But it starts with working in a collaborative effort with states and local folks. If you own the land
column10: every day is Earth Day. People care a lot about their land and care about their environment. Not all wisdom is in Washington
column11: D.C. on this issue.

column1: I'm really strongly committed to clean water and clean air
column2: and cleaning up the new kinds of challenges like global warming. He is right that I'm not in favor of energy taxes. I am in favor of tax cuts to encourage and give incentives for the quicker development of these new kinds of technologies. And let me say again
column3: Detroit is rearing to go on that. We differ on the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge
column4: as I have said. We differ on whether or not pollution controls ought to be voluntary. I don't think you can -- I don't think you can get results that way. We differ on the kinds of appointments that we would make.

column1: I think it's a fundamental difference. Let me give you an example.

column2: sure.
I don't believe in command and control out of Washington
column3: D.C. I believe Washington ought to set standards
column4: but again I think we ought to be collaborative at the local levels and I think we ought to work with people at the local levels. And by the way
column5: I just want to make sure -- I can't let him just say something and not correct it. The electric decontrol bill that I fought for and signed in Texas has mandatory emission standards
column6: Mr. Vice President. That's what we ought to do at the federal level when it comes to grandfathered plants for utilities. I think there's a difference. I think
column7: for example
column8: take -- when they took 40 million acres of land out of circulation without consulting local officials
column9: I thought that was --

column2: yeah. And so -- on the logging issue. That's not the way I would have done it. Perhaps some of that land needs to be set aside. But I certainly would have consulted with governors and elected officials before I would have acted unilaterally.
absolutely
column3: so long as they're based upon science and they're reasonable. So long as people have input.

column1: I think it's an issue that we need to take very seriously. But I don't think we know the solution to global warming yet. And I don't think we've got all the facts before we make decisions. I tell you one thing I'm not going to do is I'm not going to let the United States carry the burden for cleaning up the world's air. Like Kyoto Treaty would have done. China and India were exempted from that treaty. I think we need to be more even-handed
column2: as evidently 99 senators -- I think it was 99 senators supported that position.

that vote wasn't exactly -- a lot of the supporters of the Kyoto Treaty actually ended up voting for that because the way it was worded. But there's no doubt there's a lot of opposition to it in the Senate. I'm not for command and control techniques either. I'm for working with the groups
column3: not just with industry but also with the citizen groups and local communities to control sprawl in ways that the local communities themselves come up with. But I disagree that we don't know the cause of global warming. I think that we do. It's pollution
column4: carbon dioxide
column5: and other chemicals that are even more potent
column6: but in smaller quantities
column7: that cause this. Look
column8: the world's temperature is going up
column9: weather patterns are changing
column10: storms are getting more violent and unpredictable. What are we going to tell our children? I'm a grandfather now. I want to be able to tell my grandson when I'm in my later years that I didn't turn away from the evidence that showed that we were doing some serious harm. In my faith tradition
column11: it is -- it's written in the book of Matthew
column12: ""Where your heart is
column13: there is your treasure also."" And I believe that -- that we ought to recognize the value to our children and grandchildren of taking steps that preserve the environment in a way that's good for them.

column2: I agree. I just -- I think there has been -- some of the scientists
column3: I believe
column4: Mr. Vice President
column5: haven't they been changing their opinion a little bit on global warming? A profound scientist recently made a different --

Mr. Vice President.

column1: What the heck. I -- of course there's a lot -- look
column2: global warming needs to be taken very seriously
column3: and I take it seriously. But science
column4: there's a lot -- there's differing opinions. And before we react
column5: I think it's best to have the full accounting
column6: full understanding of what's taking place. And I think to answer your question
column7: I think both of us care a lot about the environment. We may have different approaches. We may have different approaches in terms of how we deal with local folks. I just cited an example of the administration just unilaterally acting without any input. And I remember you gave a very good answer to New Hampshire about the White Mountains
column8: about how it was important to keep that collaborative effort in place. I feel very strongly the same place. It certainly wasn't the attitude that took place out west
column9: however.

column5: you know
column6: if you know what I mean. I think credibility is important. It is going to be important for the president to be credible with Congress
column7: important for the president to be credible with foreign nations. And yes
column8: I think it's something that people need to consider. This isn't something new. I read a report
column9: or a memo
column10: from somebody in his 1988 campaign -- I forgot the fellow's name -- warning then Senator Gore to be careful about exaggerating claims. I thought during his debate with Senator Bradley saying he authored the EITC when it didn't happen. I mention the last debate --

column2: sorry.

column1: A lot of initials from a guy who's not from Washington
column2: isn't it? Anyway
column3: he co-sponsored McCain-Feingold
column4: and yet he didn't. And so I think this is an issue. I found it to be an issue in trying to defend my tax relief package. I thought there was some exaggerations about the numbers. But the people are going to have to make up their mind on this issue. And I am going to continue to defend my record and defend my propositions against what I think are exaggerations. Exaggerations like
column5: for example
column6: only 5% of seniors receive benefits under my Medicare reform package. That's what he said the other day
column7: and that's simply not the case. And I have every right in the world to defend my record and positions. That's what debates are about and that's what campaigns are about.

column1: I got some of the details wrong last week in some of the examples that I used
column2: Jim
column3: and I'm sorry about that. And I'm going to try to do better. One of the reasons I regret it is that getting a detail wrong interfered several times with the point that I was trying to make. However many days that young girl in Florida stood in her classroom
column4: however long
column5: even if it was only one day
column6: doesn't change the fact that there are a lot of overcrowded classrooms in America and we need to do something about that. There are seniors who pay more for their prescriptions than a lot of other people
column7: more than their pets
column8: sometimes. More sometimes than people in foreign countries. And we need to do something about that. Not with the measure that leaves the majority of them without any real basic help until the next president's term of four years is over. But right away. And that means doing it under the Medicare program. I can't promise that I will never get another detail wrong. I can promise you that I will try not to
column9: and hard. But I will promise you this with all the confidence in my heart and in the world
column10: that I will do my best if I'm elected president
column11: I'll work my heart out to get the big things right for the American people.

column2: that would put us into such big deficits
column3: that gives almost half the benefits to the wealthiest of the wealthy. I think anybody would have a hard time explaining that clearly in a way that makes sense to the average person.

column1: That's the kind of exaggeration I was just talking about. (LAUGHTER)

column2: I wasn't the one having trouble explaining it.

column3: 9)	" Well
column4: we all make mistakes. I've been known to mangle a syl-a-ble or two myself
column5: you know
column6: if you know what I mean. I think credibility is important. It is going to be important for the president to be credible with Congress
column7: important for the president to be credible with foreign nations. And yes
column8: I think it's something that people need to consider. This isn't something new. I read a report
column9: or a memo
column10: from somebody in his 1988 campaign -- I forgot the fellow's name -- warning then Senator Gore to be careful about exaggerating claims. I thought during his debate with Senator Bradley saying he authored the EITC when it didn't happen. I mention the last debate --

column2: sorry.

column1: A lot of initials from a guy who's not from Washington
column2: isn't it? Anyway
column3: he co-sponsored McCain-Feingold
column4: and yet he didn't. And so I think this is an issue. I found it to be an issue in trying to defend my tax relief package. I thought there was some exaggerations about the numbers. But the people are going to have to make up their mind on this issue. And I am going to continue to defend my record and defend my propositions against what I think are exaggerations. Exaggerations like
column5: for example
column6: only 5% of seniors receive benefits under my Medicare reform package. That's what he said the other day
column7: and that's simply not the case. And I have every right in the world to defend my record and positions. That's what debates are about and that's what campaigns are about.

column1: I got some of the details wrong last week in some of the examples that I used
column2: Jim
column3: and I'm sorry about that. And I'm going to try to do better. One of the reasons I regret it is that getting a detail wrong interfered several times with the point that I was trying to make. However many days that young girl in Florida stood in her classroom
column4: however long
column5: even if it was only one day
column6: doesn't change the fact that there are a lot of overcrowded classrooms in America and we need to do something about that. There are seniors who pay more for their prescriptions than a lot of other people
column7: more than their pets
column8: sometimes. More sometimes than people in foreign countries. And we need to do something about that. Not with the measure that leaves the majority of them without any real basic help until the next president's term of four years is over. But right away. And that means doing it under the Medicare program. I can't promise that I will never get another detail wrong. I can promise you that I will try not to
column9: and hard. But I will promise you this with all the confidence in my heart and in the world
column10: that I will do my best if I'm elected president
column11: I'll work my heart out to get the big things right for the American people.

column1: That's going to be up to the people
column2: isn't it?

column3: 9)	" Well
column4: we all make mistakes. I've been known to mangle a syl-a-ble or two myself
column5: you know
column6: if you know what I mean. I think credibility is important. It is going to be important for the president to be credible with Congress
column7: important for the president to be credible with foreign nations. And yes
column8: I think it's something that people need to consider. This isn't something new. I read a report
column9: or a memo
column10: from somebody in his 1988 campaign -- I forgot the fellow's name -- warning then Senator Gore to be careful about exaggerating claims. I thought during his debate with Senator Bradley saying he authored the EITC when it didn't happen. I mention the last debate --

column2: sorry.

column1: A lot of initials from a guy who's not from Washington
column2: isn't it? Anyway
column3: he co-sponsored McCain-Feingold
column4: and yet he didn't. And so I think this is an issue. I found it to be an issue in trying to defend my tax relief package. I thought there was some exaggerations about the numbers. But the people are going to have to make up their mind on this issue. And I am going to continue to defend my record and defend my propositions against what I think are exaggerations. Exaggerations like
column5: for example
column6: only 5% of seniors receive benefits under my Medicare reform package. That's what he said the other day
column7: and that's simply not the case. And I have every right in the world to defend my record and positions. That's what debates are about and that's what campaigns are about.

column1: I got some of the details wrong last week in some of the examples that I used
column2: Jim
column3: and I'm sorry about that. And I'm going to try to do better. One of the reasons I regret it is that getting a detail wrong interfered several times with the point that I was trying to make. However many days that young girl in Florida stood in her classroom
column4: however long
column5: even if it was only one day
column6: doesn't change the fact that there are a lot of overcrowded classrooms in America and we need to do something about that. There are seniors who pay more for their prescriptions than a lot of other people
column7: more than their pets
column8: sometimes. More sometimes than people in foreign countries. And we need to do something about that. Not with the measure that leaves the majority of them without any real basic help until the next president's term of four years is over. But right away. And that means doing it under the Medicare program. I can't promise that I will never get another detail wrong. I can promise you that I will try not to
column9: and hard. But I will promise you this with all the confidence in my heart and in the world
column10: that I will do my best if I'm elected president
column11: I'll work my heart out to get the big things right for the American people.

column1: That's going to be up to the people
column2: isn't it?

column1: Depends on what he says in the future in the campaign.
I hope they're not awful things. I think they may be using the man's own words.
I don't believe I've used those words.
I don't use language like that and I don't think that we should.
I understand. The -- I haven't seen that
column2: in my commercials?

column1: I think that what -- I think the point of that is that anybody would have a hard time trying to make a tax cut plan that is so large
column2: that would put us into such big deficits
column3: that gives almost half the benefits to the wealthiest of the wealthy. I think anybody would have a hard time explaining that clearly in a way that makes sense to the average person.

column1: That's the kind of exaggeration I was just talking about. (LAUGHTER)

column2: I wasn't the one having trouble explaining it.
